['#Sample analysis for Nolana using the genetic distance matrix insead of phylogeny

#load libraries that you will need
library(MCMCglmm)
library(MASS)


#Read genetic distance matrix and assign names
gd<-read.csv("nolanagd.csv",header=F)
mat<-as.matrix(gd[,2:12])


#Take generalized inverse and format for MCMCglmm
#generalized inverse of 1-gd matrix is required for the analysis
M1<-1-mat
M1a<- as(ginv(M1), "dgCMatrix")
dimnames(M1a)<-list(gd[,1],gd[,1])
#might get warning about supressing column names


#If using phylogeny instead
#Take generalized inverse and format for MCMCglmm
tree<-read.tree("nolana_ultrametric_tree.txt")
sp1inv<-inverseA(tree,nodes="TIPS")$Ainv
sp2inv<-inverseA(tree,nodes="TIPS")$Ainv
#use these matrices in place of M1a below


#Trait data
#Names in dataset need to match names for genetic distance matrix and/or phylogeny exactly
data<-read.csv("nolana.csv")

#Creating subsets of the data
#There should be no missing values for RI or the explanatory variables
total<-subset(data,!is.na(data$Total_Isolation))

#setting up uninformative priors based on y variable of interest
p.var<-var(total$Total_Isolation)

#Model potential correlation between fixed effects by making variance-covariance matrix
Bvar<-diag(4)*p.var
Bvar[Bvar==0]<-p.var/4

#prior for correlated fixed effects, residuals and two random effects "G"

prior1=list(B=list(mu=rep(0,4),V=Bvar),R=list(V=p.var/3, n=1), G=list(G1=list(V=p.var/3, n=1),G2=list(V=p.var/3,n=1)))


#Run two MCMC chains for each analysis so that we can look at diagnostics
#set seed so results can be reproduced
set.seed(1001)
m1a_1<-MCMCglmm(Total_Isolation~GeneticDistance+GeographicDistance+CorolDiam_Diff,random=~Species1+Species2,ginverse=list(Species1=M1a,Species2=M1a),prior=prior1,data=total,nitt=26000,thin=20,burnin=6000,verbose=F)

set.seed(3001)
m1a_2<-MCMCglmm(Total_Isolation~GeneticDistance+GeographicDistance+CorolDiam_Diff,random=~Species1+Species2,ginverse=list(Species1=M1a,Species2=M1a),prior=prior1,data=total,nitt=26000,thin=20,burnin=6000,verbose=F)

#Diagnostics based on gelman-rubin approach
#looking for values to be close to 1, values less than 1.1 acceptable
gelman.diag(mcmc.list(m1a_1$Sol,m1a_2$Sol))
gelman.diag(mcmc.list(m1a_1$VCV,m1a_2$VCV))

#Adding the two chains together to profile posterior distribution
m1asum<-as.mcmc(rbind(m1a_1$Sol,m1a_2$Sol))
HPDinterval(m1asum)


']
keywords: Keywords: reproductive isolation, speciation, large datasets, statistical methods, phylogenetic mixed models, evolution, predictor variables, rates, patterns, sympatric species, allopatric species, Silene, Nolana, floral differentiation, post

Paper: Estimation of excess mortality of patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in Germany
description: Source code and data of estimation of excess mortality of people with RA in Germany - for use with the statistical software R (The R Foundation of Statistical Computing)
content:
['rm(list=ls(all=TRUE))

#######################
#
###   Input data    ###
#
#######################


### Prevalence of RA in German men and women 2009 and 2015
# Steffen A et al. Epidemiologie der rheumatoiden Arthritis in Deutschland, 2017, DOI 10.20364/VA-17.08, Fig 1, p. 8
p09.m  <- 1e-2*c(0.026, 0.043, 0.065, 0.088, 0.153, 0.233, 0.334, 0.489, # Men in 2009
                 0.684, 0.811, 1.014, 1.200, 1.329, 1.292, 1.037, 0.837)
p15.m  <- 1e-2*c(0.030, 0.052, 0.076, 0.116, 0.165, 0.260, 0.401, 0.577, 
                 0.838, 1.091, 1.210, 1.483, 1.714, 1.710, 1.473, 1.068)
p09.f  <- 1e-2*c(0.078, 0.126, 0.192, 0.279, 0.424, 0.603, 0.856, 1.287, 
                 1.786, 2.027, 2.353, 2.590, 2.547, 2.198, 1.622, 0.972)
p15.f  <- 1e-2*c(0.094, 0.172, 0.243, 0.339, 0.505, 0.733, 1.013, 1.451, # Women in 2015
                 2.008, 2.443, 2.670, 3.004, 3.295, 2.945, 2.240, 1.469)
ages.p <- c(17.5+5*(0:14), 92) # midpoints of reported age groups, 92 is approx life expectancy of 90y old


# Incidence of RA (DOI 10.20364/VA-17.08, Tab 3, p. 10)
i.m    <- 1e-5*c( 9.0, 30.2,  75.4, 119.9,  97.3) # Men 2014
i.f    <- 1e-5*c(26.1, 73.3, 148.1, 188.4, 119.5) # Women 2014
ages.i <-      c(  25, 42.5,  57.5,  72.5,    87) # midpoints of reported age groups, 87 is approx life expectancy of 80y old


### General mortality in Germany (logarithmic scale)
# Period life table 2012 from Genesis database of the 
# Federal Statistical Office of Germany (DESTATIS)
log.gm.m  <- c(-8.795179291, -7.599213083, -7.548995919, -7.347645087, # men
               -7.131449529, -6.676275331, -6.145331329, -5.573655173, 
               -5.020471797, -4.564083507, -4.183849644, -3.799568641, 
               -3.314886683, -2.732839266, -2.151835594, -1.583090808)
log.gm.f  <- c(-9.741849652, -9.005136484, -8.603149634, -8.436980597, # women
               -8.179973895, -7.762456033, -7.255301367, -6.739186028, 
               -6.151846527, -5.654838109, -5.238719625, -4.836743928, 
               -4.434604996, -3.893039584, -3.187707288, -2.472702287)
ages.gm <- 15+5*0:15

### Data from Danish RA register 
# Table 1 (right part) of Loppenthin et al, Morbidity and mortality in patients with
# rheumatoid arthritis, J Comorb (9) 2019, DOI 10.1177/2235042X19853484
agPc.P  <- 1e-2*c(.9, 2.9, 6.4, 12.4, 21.4, 24.3, 21.9,  9.8) # Age distribution RA pat
agPc.C  <- 1e-2*c(.8, 2.8, 6.2, 12.0, 20.8, 24.3, 22.8, 10.4) # Age distribution controls
menPc.P <- 0.27                                               # Percentage of men in RA pat 
menPc.C <- 0.277                                              # Percentage of men in controls  
N.P     <- 21777                                              # number of RA pat
N.C     <- 91024                                              # number of controls
logHR   <- log(0.59)                                          # hazard ratio (see last paragraph of Results section)

#######################
#
###  aux functions  ###
#
#######################

logit <- function(x){
  return(log(x/(1-x)))
}

inv.logit <- function(x){
  return(exp(x)/(1+exp(x)))
}

#######################
#
### pre-processing  ###
#
#######################

ages.e  <- seq(from = 17.5, to = 92.5, by = 7.5) # ages where we want results

# sex-specific prevalences (needed for 2nd part)
logit_p1.m <- smooth.spline(ages.p, logit(p09.m), df = 7)
logit_p2.m <- smooth.spline(ages.p, logit(p15.m), df = 7)

logit_p1.f <- smooth.spline(ages.p, logit(p09.f), df = 7)
logit_p2.f <- smooth.spline(ages.p, logit(p15.f), df = 7)

get_p.m <- function(t_, a_){
  h_  <- t_ - 9.0
  p1_ <- inv.logit(predict(logit_p1.m, x = a_ - h_    )$y)
  p2_ <- inv.logit(predict(logit_p2.m, x = a_ - h_ + 6)$y)
  # affine-linear interpolation btw 2009 and 2015
  return((1 - h_/6)*p1_ + h_*p2_/6)
}

get_p.f <- function(t_, a_){
  h_  <- t_ - 9.0
  p1_ <- inv.logit(predict(logit_p1.f, x = a_ - h_    )$y)
  p2_ <- inv.logit(predict(logit_p2.f, x = a_ - h_ + 6)$y)
  # affine-linear interpolation btw 2009 and 2015
  return((1 - h_/6)*p1_ + h_*p2_/6)
}

get_p <- function(t_, a_, isMale = TRUE){
  if(isMale)
     return(get_p.m(t_, a_))
  else
     return(get_p.f(t_, a_))
}

log_i.m  <- smooth.spline(ages.i, log(i.m), df = 4)
log_i.f  <- smooth.spline(ages.i, log(i.f), df = 4)

get_i <- function(a_, isMale = TRUE){
  if(isMale)
     return(exp(predict(log_i.m, x = a_)$y))
  else
     return(exp(predict(log_i.f, x = a_)$y))
}

get_m <- function(a_, isMale = TRUE){
   if(isMale)
      return(exp(approx(ages.gm, log.gm.m, xout = ages.e, rule = 2)$y))
   else
      return(exp(approx(ages.gm, log.gm.f, xout = ages.e, rule = 2)$y))
}



#
# Estimation of range of meaningful hazard ratios
#

nSensScen <- 1e5 # number of required samples of the sensitivity

set.seed(18720518) # birthday of Bertrand Russell
snsSc.mat <- matrix(data = c( runif(length(ages.e) * nSensScen, m']
keywords: excess mortality, estimation, patients, rheumatoid arthritis, Germany, source code, data, statistical software, R Foundation, Statistical Computing

Paper: R code and example data for using genogeographic clustering approach
description: While in recent years there have been considerable advances in discerning spatial genetic patterns within species, the task of identifying common patterns across species is still challenging. Approaches using new data from co-sampled species permit rigorous statistical analysis but are often limited to a small number of species; meta-analyses of published data can encompass a much broader range of species, but are usually restricted by uneven data properties. There is a need for new approaches that bring greater statistical rigour to meta-analyses, and are also able to discern more than a single spatial pattern among species.We propose a new approach for comparative multi-species meta-analyses of published population genetic data that addresses many existing limitations. This analysis takes a three-stage approach: (i) use common genetic metrics to measure location-specific diversity across the sampled range of each species, (ii) use an innovative graphing technique to describe spatial patterns within each species, and (iii) quantitatively cluster species by their similarity in pattern. We apply this technique to 21 species of intertidal invertebrate from the New Zealand coastline, to resolve common spatial patterns from disparate profiles of genetic diversity.The genogeographic curves are shown to successfully capture the known spatial patterns within each intertidal species, and readily permit statistical comparison of those patterns, regardless of sampling and marker inconsistencies. The species clustering technique is shown to discern groups of species that clearly share spatial patterns within groups but differ significantly among groups. The species groups defined were not identifiable a priori from their taxonomy or life history, but their spatial genetic patterns appear biologically relevant.Genogeographic species clustering provides a novel approach to discerning multiple common spatial patterns of diversity among a large number of species. It will permit more rigorous comparative studies from diverse published data, and can be easily extended to a wide variety of alternative measures of genetic diversity or divergence. We see the approach best used as an exploratory method, to uncover the patterns often hidden in multi-species communities, likely to be followed by more targeted model-testing analyses.
content:
['## =============================================
## R CODE FOR GENOGEOGRAPHIC SPECIES CLUSTERING
## =============================================
## This file contains R code to perform the analyses in the following paper:
## "Genogeographic clustering to identify cross-species concordance of spatial genetic patterns",
## by V. Arranz, R.M. Fewster, and S.D. Lavery.
##
## All code in this file is written by Rachel Fewster, r.fewster@auckland.ac.nz.

## =============================================
## DATA FILES NEEDED:
## =============================================
## Two data files are needed:
##
## 1. Coastline data: e.g. New-Zealand-Coastline-Lat-Long.csv.
## This CSV contains three columns: X (longitude), Y (latitude), and Distance.
## X and Y give the coordinates of the coastline of interest at a fine scale.
## Distance is the value of the linear spatial coordinate corresponding to each (X, Y) location.
## The code below assumes that the coastline follows a closed loop; otherwise  some adjustments are needed.
##
## 2. Species data: e.g. All-Species-Data-for-H.csv.
## This has three columns: Species, Distance, and a third column that gives the value of a genetic metric
## of interest. The name of the third column will be automatically detected, so different genetic metrics can
## easily be used.  However, to detect the correct measure, it is assumed that the genetic metric is in the
## column immediately after the Distance column. Other arrangements of columns will be incorrectly interpreted.
## Data columns are as follows:
## - The Species column gives the species sampled at a location.
## - The Distance column gives the value of the linear spatial coordinate at the sampling location.
## This is the same linear spatial coordinate used in the coastline data file. In our case it is the distance of
## the sampling location from Cape Reinga, in km, following a clockwise trajectory around New Zealand.
## - The third column gives the value of the genetic measure for the corresponding species at the sampling
## location.  Any measure can be inserted here, but it is assumed that the measure is a number between 0 and 1.


## =============================================
## PRELIMINARY SET-UP:
## =============================================
## The code below establishes the coastal coordinates and species list.
## It is run every time this code file is sourced.

## Load packages (these must be installed first):
require(RColorBrewer)

## Read in the coordinates of the coastline from the coastline data file, e.g. New-Zealand-Coastline-Lat-Long.csv.
## This CSV contains three columns: X (Longitude), Y (Latitude), and Distance, where Distance is the value of
## the linear spatial coordinate corresponding to each (X, Y) location.  The resulting R object "coastdat" is used
## as a lookup table for converting between Distance and (X, Y), and also for plotting colour-maps of the results.
coastdat <- read.csv("New-Zealand-Coastline-Lat-Long.csv", as.is=T)

## Define the species included in the analyses: there are 21 species in our dataset.
## Each of the species named must be included in the data CSV (see All-Species-Data-for-H.csv for an example).
all.species <- c("Asqu", "Astu", "Aten", "CglaspA", "CglaspC", "Corn",
                 "Crad", "Echlo", "Hiris", "Hsex", "Lsma", "Paus", "Pcan", "Pelo",
                 "Pnov", "Preg", "Psub", "Sbre", "Spel", "Zlut", "Zsub")

## Define a fixed set of colours so that each species is always plotted in the same colour:
colour.standard <- c("black", "red", "darksalmon", "blue", "cyan", "magenta", "yellow", "gray",
                     "maroon", "orange", "purple", "green3", "sienna", "#66A61E", "#E7298A",
                     "#7570B3", "#D95F02", "#1B9E77", "plum3", "tan2", "steelblue")


## =============================================
## COMMANDS TO RUN ANALYSES:
## =============================================
## The code below is enclosed in an if(FALSE){..} statement, which acts as a large comment block.
## To run the code, copy and paste the commands below into R.

if(F){
        ## Begin by sourcing this code:
        source("Genogeographic-Cluster-Code.R")

        ## =========================================
        ## FIT THE GENOGEOGRAPHIC CURVES
        ## =========================================
        ## Fit genogeographic curves to the data supplied using default selections for all options.
        ## Press Enter to scroll to the second page, or use argument autoscroll=TRUE.
        res.curves.H <- fitspline.wrap("All-Species-Data-for-H.csv")
        ## NOTE: fitspline.wrap is set to scale-and-centre curves by default. If this is not wanted, use argument
        ## scaleAndCentre=FALSE.

        ## Under the default options, the object returned in res.curves.H is a data-frame with a column for
        ## each species in the CSV file, and with 1000 rows giving the curve height for each species at each
        ## of 1000 equally-spaced points along the distanc']
keywords: genogeographic, clustering approach, R code, example data, spatial genetic patterns, species, co-sampled, statistical analysis, meta-analyses, published data, common genetic metrics, location-specific diversity, graphing technique, intertidal in

Paper: Robust SOM Clustering
description: This R script performs a combined SOM/SuperSOM clustering of the 640 administrative districs of India. Fowlkes-Mallows Similarity Index is used to identify robust initializations of the clustering. Data_India.txt is a specially conceived geographic database of 55 indicators, covering issues of economic activity, urban structure, socio-demographic development, consumption levels, infrastructure endowment and basic geographical positioning within the Indian space. Data refer to 2011 or to 2001-2011 evolutions.Warnng: This is an old version of the project. Version 1.2 available at https://zenodo.org/record/2563213#.XGQl01xKiiz
content:
['####################################################################################
#                                                                                  #
# An R script to perform combined SOM/superSOM data clustering                     #
#                                                                                  #
# AuthorS: Joan Perez                                                              #
#          Univ. Avignon Pays du Vaucluse, CNRS, ESPACE, UMR7300                   #
#          Case Pasteur, Avignon                                                   #
#          E-mail: joan.perez.etu@gmail.com                                        # 
#                                                                                  #
#          Giovanni Fusco                                                          #
#          Univ. Cte d'Azur, CNRS, ESPACE, UMR7300                                #
#          98 Bd Herriot, BP 3209, 06204 Nice, France                              #
#          E-mail: giovanni.fusco@unice.fr                                         #
#                                                                                  #
####################################################################################

# This script performs a combined SOM/SuperSOM clustering of the 640 administrative districts of India.
# Fowlkes-Mallows Similarity Index is used to identify robust initializations of the clustering.
# Data_India.txt is a specially conceived geographic database of 55 indicators, covering issues of economic activity,
# urban structure, socio-demographic development, consumption levels, infrastructure endowment and 
# basic geographical positioning within the Indian space. Data refer to 2011 or to 2001-2011 evolutions.

# References:
# [1] Wehrens R., Buydens L., 2007, Self- and Super-organizing Maps in R: The ko-honen Package,
#     Journal of Statistical Software, Vol. 21, Issue 5.
# [2] Fusco G., Perez J., 2015, Spatial Analysis of the Indian Subcontinent: the Complexity Investigated 
#     through Neural Networks, CUPUM 2015 - 14th International Conference on Computers in Urban Planning 
#     and Urban Management, MIT, Cambridge (Ma.), July 5th-7th 2015, Proceedings, 287, 1-20,
#     http://web.mit.edu/cron/project/CUPUM2015/proceedings/Content/analytics/287_fusco_h.pdf 
# [3] Perez J., 2015, Spatial Structures in India in the Age of Globalisation. A Data-Driven Approach, Phd in geography,
#     University of Avignon (France)


####################################################################################
# 0.1 : Environment Preparation                                                    #
####################################################################################

# Packages loading (needs to be previously installed)
library(MASS)
library(class)
library(kohonen)
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(dendextend))

####################################################################################
# 0.2. General Functions and Utilities                                             #
####################################################################################

## 0.2.1 Automated Number of Primes Selection / Initialization                       

select.primes <- function(nb)
{
  primes <- vector()
  t <- 0
  a <- 3
  while (length(primes)<nb) {for (i in a) { for (j in 2:(i-1)) {if (i %% j == 0){t <- (t+1)} } 
                                            if (t==0){primes<- c(primes,i)}
                                            t <- 0
  }
  a <- (a+1)
  }
  return(primes)
}

## 0.2.2 Calculation of the Best Similarity Score for each Seed

# function returns two arguments, first one is the best seed in chr
# second one is the average similarity score for each seed
FM.Similarity <- function(results.list, clusters)
{
FM.matrix <- matrix(nrow=length(results.list), ncol=length(results.list))
for(i in 1:length(results.list)) {for(j in 1:length(results.list)) 
{FM.matrix[i,j]<-FM_index_R(clusters[,i+1],clusters[,j+1],assume_sorted_vectors = TRUE) }}
rownames(FM.matrix) <- c(paste0("seed", primes))
colnames(FM.matrix) <- c(paste0("seed", primes))
average <- apply(FM.matrix, 1, mean)
FM.df <- as.data.frame(cbind(FM.matrix, average))
best.seed <- row.names (FM.df[which.max(FM.df$average),])
best.seed <- paste0("cluster.",best.seed)
output <- list(best.seed, average)
return(output)
}

####################################################################################
# 0.3 Prerequise on Df Origin                                                      #
####################################################################################

# Importation of the main database completed using bayesian inference, including NA
df.origin <- read.delim2("Data_India.txt")

# Base 10 log transformation of Air_Flows
# Replace -Inf by 0 within the dataframe
# Replace N']
keywords: Robust SOM, Clustering, R Script, India, Administrative districts, Fowlkes-Mallows Similarity Index, Data_India.txt, Geographic database, Economic activity, Urban structure, Socio-demographic development, Consumption levels, Infrastructure endowment

Paper: Involvement of Burkholderiaceae and sulfurous volatiles in disease suppressive soils
description: Scripts for statistical analysis and graphs of the publication " Involvement of Burkholderiaceae and sulfurous volatiles in disease suppressive soils ".
content:
['############################################################################################
#                                                                                          #
# Metabolomics analysis - PCA/PLSDA/SPLSDA                                                 #
#                                                                                          #
#                                                                                          #
# Victor J. Carrion                                                                        #
# Netherlands Institute of Ecology                                                         #
# v.carrion@nioo.knaw.nl                                                                   #  
# victorcarrionbravo@hotmail.com                                                           #
#                                                                                          #
############################################################################################

library(mixOmics)
library(ggplot2)
library(reshape2)
library(ggdendro)
library(grid)


#Figure 2####
#Figure 2B
inputVOCs <- read.table("1_input_DI.txt", header = TRUE, sep = "\t")
p <- ggplot(data = inputVOCs, aes(x=Treatment, y=DI)) + geom_boxplot(aes(fill=Treatment), width = 0.8) +
  theme_bw() + 
  theme(axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"),
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        panel.background = element_blank())
p + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("white","white","white","white","white","white","gray","black","white"))  + theme (axis.text=element_text(size=15))

#Figure 3####
#Figure 3B
inputVOCs <- read.table("2_input_in_vitro_VOCs.txt", header = TRUE, sep = "\t")
p <- ggplot(data = inputVOCs, aes(x=Treatment, y=day4)) + geom_boxplot(aes(fill=Treatment), width = 0.8) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"),
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        panel.background = element_blank())
p + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("green4", "royalblue","sienna2","grey","palevioletred3", "white")) + theme (axis.text=element_text(size=15))


#Figure 3C

wild <- read.table("3_input_pareto_norm.txt", sep="\t", header = TRUE)

head(wild)
tail(wild)
X_wild <- (wild[, 3:503])
head(X_wild)
tail(X_wild)
group_wild <- wild[, 2]
head(group_wild)

#Preliminary analysis with PCA: PCA analysis on the volatomic data.
pca.wild <- pca(X_wild, ncomp = 3, center = TRUE, scale = TRUE)
pca.wild
plot(pca.wild)

#PCA with centroids
plotIndiv(pca.wild, group = wild$Group, ind.names = FALSE, 
          ellipse = TRUE, legend = TRUE, title = 'VOCs Burkholderia spp.', 
          size.xlabel = 20, size.ylabel = 20, size.axis = 25, pch = 15, cex = 5)

#PCA without centroids
plotIndiv(pca.wild, group = wild$Group, ind.names = FALSE, 
          ellipse = FALSE, legend = TRUE, title = 'VOCs Burkholderia spp.', 
          size.xlabel = 20, size.ylabel = 20, size.axis = 25, pch = 15, cex = 5)


#PLS-DA analysis
#The PLS-DA and sPLS-DA analyses below will help refine the clusters of samples in a supervised fashion. 
Y_wild <- wild$Group
summary(Y_wild)


#this chunk takes ~ 5 min to run
set.seed(32) # for reproducibility of the outputs of this code that performs random cross-validation sampling. 
wild.plsda.perf <- plsda(X_wild, Y_wild, ncomp = 6)
# to speed up computation in this example we choose 5 folds repeated 10 times:
wild.perf.plsda <- perf(wild.plsda.perf, validation = 'Mfold', folds = 6,
                        progressBar = FALSE, nrepeat = 10)

head(wild.perf.plsda$error.rate)

plot(wild.perf.plsda, overlay = 'measure', sd=TRUE)

wild.plsda <- plsda(X_wild, Y_wild, ncomp = 10)

#PLS-DA with centroids
plotIndiv(wild.plsda , comp = c(1,2),
          group = wild$Group, ind.names = FALSE, 
          ellipse = TRUE, legend = TRUE, title = 'wild, PLSDA comp 1 - 2')

plot(wild.perf.plsda, overlay = 'measure', sd=TRUE)



wild.plsda <- plsda(X_wild, Y_wild, ncomp = 10)

#PLS-DA without centroids
plotIndiv(wild.plsda , comp = c(1,2),
          group = wild$Group, style = 'ggplot2', ind.names = FALSE, 
          ellipse = TRUE, legend = TRUE, title = 'VOCs Burkholderia spp.', 
          size.xlabel = 20, size.ylabel = 20, size.axis = 25, pch = 15, cex = 5)

#Figure 3D
#differential abundance wild

df <-read.delim("4_stats_KW_BH_dot_plot.txt", header = T, sep = "\t")
head(df, 10)

g<-ggplot(df, aes(x=RT, y=Pgave_ratio)) +
  geom_point(size=6, colour=df$Class_ratio_stats, pch=20)  +
  theme_bw() 
g +   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
            panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", colour = "black",
                                            linetype = 0.5, size = 1.5),
            axis.ticks = element_line(colour = "black")']
keywords: Burkholderiaceae, sulfurous volatiles, disease suppressive soils, statistical analysis, graphs, publication.

Paper: Data from: Transcriptomic plasticity of mesophotic corals among natural populations and transplants of Montastraea cavernosa in the Gulf of Mexico and Belize
description: While physiological responses to low-light environments have been studied among corals on mesophotic coral ecosystems worldwide (MCEs; 30150 m), the mechanisms behind acclimatization and adaptation to depth are not well understood for most coral species. Transcriptomic approaches based on RNA sequencing are useful tools for quantifying gene expression plasticity, particularly in slow-growing species such as scleractinian corals, and for identifying potential functional differences among conspecifics. A tag-based RNA-Seq (Tag-Seq) pipeline was applied to quantify transcriptional variation in natural populations of the scleractinian coral Montastraea cavernosa from mesophotic and shallower environments across five sites in Belize and the Gulf of Mexico: Carrie Bow Cay, West and East Flower Garden Banks, Pulley Ridge, and Dry Tortugas. Regional site location was a stronger driver of gene expression patterns than depth. However, mesophotic corals among all sites shared similar regulation of metabolic and cell growth functional pathways that may represent common physiological responses to environmental conditions at depth. Additionally, in a transplant experiment at West and East Flower Garden Banks, colonies transplanted from mesophotic to shallower habitats diverged from the control mesophotic group over time, indicating depth-regulated plasticity of gene expression. When the shallower depth zone experienced a bleaching event, bleaching severity did not differ significantly between transplants and shallow controls, but gene expression patterns indicated variable regulation of stress responses among depth treatments. Coupled observational and experimental studies of gene expression among mesophotic and shallower M. cavernosa provide insights into the ability of this depth-generalist coral species to persist under varying environmental conditions.

['setwd("~/path/to/local/directory")

#---------------------
# assembling data, running outlier detection, and fitting models
# (skip this section if you don't need to remake models)

library(DESeq2)
library(arrayQualityMetrics)

#read in counts
counts = read.table("allcounts_enviro_mcav.txt")

# how many genes we have total?
nrow(counts) 
ncol(counts)

# how does the data look? 
head(counts)

#---------------------
keep <- rowSums(counts) >= 10
countData <- counts[keep,]
nrow(countData)
ncol(countData)
write.csv(countData, file="countData.csv")

# importing a design .csv file
design = read.csv("design_enviro.csv", head=TRUE)
design
str(design)

# make big dataframe including all factors and interaction, getting normalized data for outlier detection
dds = DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData=countData, colData=design, design=~ site+depth+site:depth)

# reorders treatment factor according to "control" vs "treatment" levels
dds$depth <- factor(dds$depth, levels = c("shallow","mesophotic"))

# for large datasets, rlog may take too much time, especially for an unfiltered dataframe
# vsd is much faster and still works for outlier detection
Vsd=varianceStabilizingTransformation(dds)
# rl=rlog(dds)

library(Biobase)
e=ExpressionSet(assay(Vsd), AnnotatedDataFrame(as.data.frame(colData(Vsd))))
# e=ExpressionSet(assay(rl), AnnotatedDataFrame(as.data.frame(colData(rl))))

# running outlier detection
arrayQualityMetrics(e,intgroup=c("site","depth"),force=T)
# dev.off()
# open the directory "arrayQualityMetrics report for e" in your working directory and open index.html
# Array metadata and outlier detection overview gives a report of all samples, and which are likely outliers according to the 3 methods tested. I typically remove the samples that violate *1 (distance between arrays).
# Figure 2 shows a bar plot of array-to-array distances and an outlier detection threshold based on your samples. Samples above the threshold are considered outliers
# under Figure 3: Principal Components Analyses, look for any points far away from the rest of the sample cluster
# use the array number for removal in the following section

## if there were outliers, say, sample number MS_043 (array 42):
outs=c(150)
countData=countData[,-outs]
Vsd=Vsd[,-outs]
# rl=rl[,-outs]
design=design[-outs,]

# remaking model with outliers removed from dataset
dds = DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData=countData, colData=design, design=~ site+depth+site:depth)
dds$depth <- factor(dds$depth, levels = c("shallow","mesophotic"))

# save all these dataframes as an Rdata package so you don't need to rerun each time
save(dds,design,countData,Vsd,file="initial.RData")
# save(dds,design,countData,rl,file="initial.RData")

#---------------------
# generating normalized variance-stabilized data for PCoA, heatmaps, etc

load("initial.RData")
library(DESeq2)
library(BiocParallel)

# creating normalized dataframe
vsd=assay(Vsd)
# vsd=assay(rl)
# takes the sample IDs and factor levels from the design to create new column names for the dataframe
snames=paste(colnames(countData),design[,2],design[,3],sep=".")
# renames the column names
colnames(vsd)=snames
save(vsd,design,file="vsd.RData")

#-------------------
# EXPLORING SIMILARITIES AMONG SAMPLES

# heatmap and hierarchical clustering:
load("vsd.RData")
library(pheatmap)
# similarity among samples
pdf(file="heatmap_enviro_mcav.pdf", width=50, height=50)
pheatmap(cor(vsd))
dev.off()

# Principal coordinates analysis
library(vegan)
library(rgl)
library(ape)

conditions=design
conditions$site <- factor(conditions$site, levels = c("BLZ","WFGB","EFGB","PRG-DRT"))

# creating a PCoA eigenvalue matrix
dds.pcoa=pcoa(dist(t(vsd),method="manhattan")/1000)
scores=dds.pcoa$vectors

# how many good PC's do we have? Compared to random ("broken stick") model
# plotting PCoA eigenvalues
pdf(file="PCoA_Manhattan.pdf", width=6, height=6)
plot(dds.pcoa$values$Relative_eig)
points(dds.pcoa$values$Broken_stick,col="red",pch=3)
dev.off()
# the number of black points above the line of red crosses (random model) corresponds to the number of good PC's

# plotting PCoA
pdf(file="PCoA_enviro_mcav.pdf", width=12, height=6)
par(mfrow=c(1,2))
plot(scores[,1], scores[,2],col=c("#f6e8c3","#01665e","#5ab4ac","#8c510a")[as.numeric(as.factor(conditions$site))],pch=c(19,17)[as.numeric(as.factor(conditions$depth))], xlab="Coordinate 1", ylab="Coordinate 2", main="Site")
# cluster overlay of site
ordiellipse(scores, conditions$site, label=F, draw= "po', 'setwd("~/path/to/local/directory")
getwd()

#---------------------------
# full model, assessing changes in KOG expression across site and depth

# loading KOG annotations
gene2kog=read.table("Mcavernosa_Cladocopium_iso2kogClass.tab",sep="\t")
head(gene2kog)

add=load('depth_lpv.RData')
add # names of datasets in the package
lpv.d=kog.mwu(depth.p,gene2kog) 
lpv.d 

ads=load('site_lpv.RData')
ads # names of datasets in the package
lpv.s=kog.mwu(site.p,gene2kog) 
lpv.s 

adi=load('int_lpv.RData')
adi # names of datasets in the package
lpv.i=kog.mwu(int.p,gene2kog) 
lpv.i

barplot(lpv.d$delta.rank,horiz=T)

# compiling a table of delta-ranks to compare these results:
ktable=makeDeltaRanksTable(list("Site"=lpv.s,"Depth"=lpv.d,"Site:Depth"=lpv.i))

library(RColorBrewer)
color = colorRampPalette(rev(c(brewer.pal(n = 7, name ="RdBu"),"royalblue","darkblue")))(100)
  
# Making a heatmap with hierarchical clustering trees: 
pdf(file="enviro_mcav_heatmap_enviro_lpv.pdf", width=7, height=7)
pheatmap(as.matrix(ktable),clustering_distance_cols="correlation",color=color, cellwidth=15, cellheight=15, border_color="white") 
while (!is.null(dev.list()))  dev.off()

# exploring correlations between datasets
pdf(file="enviro_mcav_corrplot_enviro_lpv.pdf", width=6, height=6)
pairs(ktable, lower.panel = panel.smooth, upper.panel = panel.cor)
while (!is.null(dev.list()))  dev.off()
#scatterplots between pairs
# p-values of these correlations in the upper panel:
pdf(file="enviro_mcav_pvalplot_enviro_lpv.pdf", width=6, height=6)
pairs(ktable, lower.panel = panel.smooth, upper.panel = panel.cor.pval)
while (!is.null(dev.list()))  dev.off()

WFGB.common

EFGB.common

# library(RColorBrewer)
# color = colorRampPalette(rev(c(brewer.pal(n = 7, name ="RdYlBu"),', '# run these once, then comment out
# install.packages("MANOVA.RM")
# install.packages("vegan")
# install.packages("RVAideMemoire")

library(MANOVA.RM)
library(vegan)
library(RVAideMemoire)
library(rcompanion)

setwd("~/path/to/local/directory")
#--------------------------------------------
# Data import
transplant <- read.csv(file="FGB_Oct15-Sep16_transplant.csv",header=TRUE,sep=",")

#displays the format of all variables in the dataframe
str(transplant)
# converts colony variable from integer to factor for statistical analyses
transplant$colony <- as.factor(transplant$colony)
# transplant$time <- as.numeric(transplant$time)
str(transplant)
transplant

# Data transformations for large numbers
# performs linear transformation on variables with numbers in the millions to make it easier to graph
transplant$zoox_cm <- transplant$zoox_cm/1000000
# transplant$chla_cm <- transplant$chla_cm/1000000
# transplant$chlc_cm <- transplant$chlc_cm/1000000
str(transplant)

#--------------------------------------------
# Normality tests

# creates a PDF for all the histograms
pdf("transplant_hist.pdf", height=6, width=12)
# creates a plot window with 2 columns and 3 rows
par(mfrow=c(2,3))
# creates a histogram of data values for each variable
hist(transplant$zoox_cm, breaks=15, xlab= expression(10^6 ~ cells ~ cm^-2), main=expression(Symbionts ~ cm^-2), col="grey50")
hist(transplant$chla_cm, breaks=15, xlab= expression(ug ~ cm^-2), main=expression(Chl ~ a ~ cm^-2), col="grey50")
hist(transplant$chlc_cm, breaks=15, xlab= expression(ug ~ cm^-2), main=expression(Chl ~ c[2] ~ cm^-2), col="grey50")
hist(transplant$chl_ac, breaks=15, xlab= NA, main=expression(Chl ~ a:c[2]), col="grey50")
hist(transplant$chla_cell, breaks=15, xlab= expression(pg ~ cell^-1), main=expression(Chl ~ a ~ cell^-1), col="grey50")
hist(transplant$chlc_cell, breaks=15, xlab= expression(pg ~ cell^-1), main=expression(Chl ~ c[2] ~ cell^-1), col="grey50")
# stops plotting, final save of the file
dev.off()

# runs a statistical test (Shapiro test) to determine if the data violates the assumptions of normality
# p < 0.05 means non-normal data
shapiro.test(transplant$zoox_cm)
shapiro.test(transplant$chla_cm)
shapiro.test(transplant$chlc_cm)
shapiro.test(transplant$chl_ac)
shapiro.test(transplant$chla_cell)
shapiro.test(transplant$chlc_cell)
# copy the output from each of these tests into a .txt file

#----------------------------------------------
# univariate repeated measures PERMANOVAs
# run one for each response variable

zoox_cm.rm <- RM(zoox_cm ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, subject="colony", resampling="Perm", CPU=8)
chla_cm.rm <- RM(chla_cm ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, subject="colony", resampling="Perm", CPU=8)
chlc_cm.rm <- RM(chlc_cm ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, subject="colony", resampling="Perm", CPU=8)
chl_ac.rm <- RM(chl_ac ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, subject="colony", resampling="Perm", CPU=8)
chla_cell.rm <- RM(chla_cell ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, subject="colony", resampling="Perm", CPU=8)
chlc_cell.rm <- RM(chlc_cell ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, subject="colony", resampling="Perm", CPU=8)

# copy the outputs of each of these objects into the same .txt file as before
# the ANOVA-Type Statistic tables contain the p values you want to report
zoox_cm.rm
chla_cm.rm
chlc_cm.rm
chl_ac.rm
chla_cell.rm
chlc_cell.rm

#----------------------------------------------
# 3-way PERMANOVA
# non-parametric multivariate test to identify effects of site, depth, and time on the 6 response variables
# using the adonis function, creates a dissimilarity matrix of all the response variables "transplant[c(7:12)]" and tests it against all factors
permanova <- adonis(transplant[c(6:11)] ~ site * depth * time, data=transplant, method="euclidian")
# copy the outputs of this object into the same .txt file as before
permanova
# pairwise comparisons for depth and time
# no need for site as there are only 2 factor levels (wb, eb)
depth.pair <- pairwise.perm.manova(transplant[c(6:11)], transplant$depth, nperm=999)
time.pair <- pairwise.perm.manova(transplant[c(6:11)], transplant$time, nperm=999)
# copy the outputs of each of these objects into the same .txt file as before
depth.pair
time.pair

#----------------------------------------------
#----------------------------------------------
# % change zoox density as a bleaching metric

bleach <- read.csv(file="FGB_Oct15-Sep16_bleaching.csv",header=TRUE,sep=",")
str(bleach)
bleach$colony <- as.factor(bleach$colony)
str(bleach)

shapiro.test(bleach$bleach)

# log transformation
bleach$bleach.log <- log(bleach$bleach+1)
str(bleach)

shapiro.test(bleach$bleach.log)

pdf("bleaching_hist.pdf", height=8, width=5)
par(mfrow=c(2,1))
hist(bleach$bleach, breaks=15, xlab= "% remaining", main="Symbiont density May 2016-Sept 2016", col="grey50")
hist(bleach$bleach.log, breaks=15, xlab= "log % remaining", main="Log symbiont density May 2016-Sept 2016", col="grey50")
dev.off()

#-', '# install.packages("EnvStats")
library(EnvStats)

#------------------------------------------------
#data import
setwd("~/path/to/local/directory")
fgb_templight = read.csv("FGBOct15-Oct16_HOBO_templight.csv", head=TRUE)
head(fgb_templight)
tail(fgb_templight)
str(fgb_templight)

#-------------------------------------------------
# converting lux to PAR (following equation in Valiela (1995))
fgb_templight$maxPAR <- fgb_templight$maxlight/51.2
fgb_templight$avgPAR <- fgb_templight$avglight/51.2
str(fgb_templight)

#---------------------------------------------------
#subsetting dataset to exclude McGrail for full factorial design
fgb_templight_EW <- subset(fgb_templight, Site != "McGrail")
fgb_templight_EW$Site=factor(fgb_templight_EW$Site, levels=unique(fgb_templight_EW$Site)) 
head(fgb_templight_EW)
tail(fgb_templight_EW)
str(fgb_templight_EW)

#---------------------------------------------------
#calculating means for Site and depth

mintemp.mean <- aggregate(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp, by=list(fgb_templight_EW$Site, fgb_templight_EW$Depth),FUN='mean')
colnames(mintemp.mean) <- c("Site", "Depth", "mintemp")
mintemp.mean

maxtemp.mean <- aggregate(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp, by=list(fgb_templight_EW$Site, fgb_templight_EW$Depth),FUN='mean')
colnames(maxtemp.mean) <- c("Site", "Depth", "maxtemp")
maxtemp.mean

avgtemp.mean <- aggregate(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp, by=list(fgb_templight_EW$Site, fgb_templight_EW$Depth),FUN='mean')
colnames(avgtemp.mean) <- c("Site", "Depth", "avgtemp")
avgtemp.mean

maxPAR.mean <- aggregate(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR, by=list(fgb_templight_EW$Site, fgb_templight_EW$Depth),FUN='mean', na.rm=TRUE)
colnames(maxPAR.mean) <- c("Site", "Depth", "maxPAR")
maxPAR.mean

avgPAR.mean <- aggregate(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR, by=list(fgb_templight_EW$Site, fgb_templight_EW$Depth),FUN='mean', na.rm=TRUE)
colnames(avgPAR.mean) <- c("Site", "Depth", "avgPAR")
avgPAR.mean

#---------------------------------------------------
#normality tests

#Q-Q plots
data=fgb_templight_EW
pdf("Q-Q Plot mintemp.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp, main="Q-Q Plot mintemp")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot maxtemp.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp, main="Q-Q Plot maxtemp")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot avgtemp.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp, main="Q-Q Plot avgtemp")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot maxPAR.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR, main="Q-Q Plot maxPAR")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot avgPAR.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR, main="Q-Q Plot avgPAR")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR)
dev.off()

#Shapiro-Wilk test, p<0.05 indicates non-normality
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp)
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp)
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp)

shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR)
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR)

#--------------------------------------------------
#data transformation

boxcox(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp, optimize=TRUE)
# Optimal Value:                   lambda = -1.404298
boxcox(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp, optimize=TRUE)
# Optimal Value:                   lambda = -1.133448
boxcox(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp, optimize=TRUE)
# Optimal Value:                   lambda = -1.188773

boxcox(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR, optimize=TRUE)
# Optimal Value:                   lambda = 0.03973649
boxcox(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR, optimize=TRUE)
# Optimal Value:                   lambda = 0.07758381


# applying the BoxCox recommended transformation
fgb_templight_EW$mintemp.log <- (fgb_templight_EW$mintemp ^ -1.404298 - 1)/-1.404298
fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp.log <- (fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp ^ -1.133448 - 1)/-1.133448
fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp.log <- (fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp ^ -1.188773 - 1)/-1.188773

fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR.log <- (fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR ^ 0.03973649 - 1)/0.03973649
fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR.log <- (fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR ^ 0.07758381 - 1)/0.07758381

head(fgb_templight_EW)
str(fgb_templight_EW)

#Q-Q plots
pdf("Q-Q Plot mintemp-log.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp.log, main="Q-Q Plot mintemp.log")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp.log)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot maxtemp-log.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp.log, main="Q-Q Plot maxtemp.log")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp.log)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot avgtemp-log.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp.log, main="Q-Q Plot avgtemp.log")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp.log)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot maxPAR-log.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR.log, main="Q-Q Plot maxPAR.log")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR.log)
dev.off()

pdf("Q-Q Plot avgPAR-log.pdf")
qqnorm(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR.log, main="Q-Q Plot avgPAR.log")
qqline(fgb_templight_EW$avgPAR.log)
dev.off()

#Shapiro-Wilk test, p<0.05 indicates non-normality
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$mintemp.log)
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$maxtemp.log)
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$avgtemp.log)

shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$maxPAR.log)
shapiro.test(fgb_templight_EW$avgP']
keywords: Transcriptomic plasticity, Mesophotic corals, Montastraea cavernosa, Gulf of Mexico, Belize, RNA sequencing, gene expression, acclimatization, adaptation, depth, scleractinian corals, metabolic pathways,

Paper: Data from: Morphometrics and redescription of Aphyllon fasciculatum and Aphyllon franciscanum (Orobanchaceae), two widespread but previously conflated species in western North America
description: We continue the taxonomic reevaluation of Aphyllon sect. Aphyllon by describing a widespread species throughout Western North America previously recognized within a polyphyletic A. fasciculatum. To support our description and revised key, we analyzed fifteen continuous and discrete characters across 156 herbarium specimens and iNaturalist observations sampled from across the geographic range. Principal component and multiple correspondence analyses reveal clear variation in floral characters. Discriminant analyses show that floral color, the calyx cup to calyx lobe ratio, calyx lobe length, and degree of bend in the corolla tube are useful distinguishing features, but not diagnostic in every case.
content:
['## Analyses for Schneider and Benton 2021. Morphometrics and redescription of Aphyllon fasciculatum and Aphyllon franciscanum, two widespread but previously conflated species in western North America. Systematic Botany.

## LINEAR DISCRIMINANT ANALYSIS##
library(tidyverse) #version 1.3.0
library(MASS) #version 7.3-51.4
library(klaR) #version 06-14
lda_data=read.csv(file.choose()) ## use "PCA_normalized_data.csv" to be sure data is normalized with mean=0 sd=1

complete = lda(Species~., data=lda_data[,1:9])
complete ##prints coefficients and group means

##Measuring accuracy via jackknife validation
jackknife <- lda(Species~., data=lda_data, CV=TRUE)
accJack <- table(lda_data$Species[,1:9], jackknife$class)
accJack
sum(accJack[row(accJack) == col(accJack)]) / sum(accJack)

## MULTIPLE CORRESPONDENCE ANALYSIS ##
library("FactoMineR") #version 2.3
library("factoextra") #version 1.0.7

#read in data
MCA_data=read.csv(file.choose()) # file= "MCA_all.csv" or "MCA_confirmed_host.csv"
summary(MCA_data)

data= MCA_data[,1:7] #remove Species ID from dataset

Aph.mca <-MCA(data, graph=FALSE)

##plot variable groups vs. principal dimensions
fviz_mca_biplot(Aph.mca, choice = "mca.cor", 
            repel = TRUE,            
            ggtheme = theme_minimal(),
            shape.ind = 1,
            shape.var = 2)
            
##plot variables vs. principal dimensions
fviz_mca_biplot(Aph.mca, 
            repel = TRUE,            
            ggtheme = theme_minimal(),
             col.ind= "gray40",geom.ind= "point")

## DISCRIMINANT CORRESPONDENCE ANALYSIS ##
##TExPosition manual: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/TExPosition/TExPosition.pdf

library(TExPosition) #version 2.6.10.1
DCA_data=read.csv(file.choose()) #read in same files as for MCA.
summary(DCA_data)

data = DCA_data[,1:7]
design=DCA_data[,14:15]
dca=tepDICA(data, make_data_nominal = T, DESIGN=design)

dca$TExPosition.Data$fj #variable loadings
dca$TExPosition.Data$eigs #eigenvalue
dca$TExPosition.Data$assign$confusion #confusion matrix
dca$TExPosition.Data$assign$r2 #r squared

## To investigate a reduced data set, simply drop/subset columns
reduced.data = data[,c(1,2,3,5)]
reduced.dca=tepDICA(reduced.data, make_data_nominal = T, DESIGN=design)']
keywords: morphometrics, redescription, Aphyllon fasciculatum, Aphyllon franciscanum, Orobanchaceae, taxonomic reevaluation, Western North America, polyphyletic, herbarium specimens, i

Paper: Extracted data from primary literature examining impacts of recreational activities on freshwater ecosystems
description: Aquatic ecosystems are attractive sites for recreation. However, human presence at or on aquatic ecosystems can have a range of ecological impacts, creating trade-offs between recreation as ecosystem service and biodiversity conservation. There is currently no synthesis of evidence regarding the ecological impacts associated with various forms of aquatic recreation, to compare the magnitude of effects between types of recreation. Therefore, conservation conflicts surrounding water-based recreation are difficult to manage. We conducted a global meta-analysis, differentiating various recreational impacts and the type of recreational uses in four categories: shore use, shoreline angling, swimming and boating; and studied ecological impacts directed at three levels of biological organization: individuals, populations, and communities. We screened over 13,000 articles and identified 94 suitable studies providing 701 effect sizes for inclusion in the meta-analysis. Aggregated across all animal and plant taxa, impacts of boating and shore use resulted in highly significant effects on almost all levels of biological organization. Regarding taxonomic groups, the most negative effects of water-based recreation were observed in invertebrates, whereas effects on birds were most pronounced at individual levels and not significant at community levels. From a conservation perspective, fostering water-based recreation and the ecological services they provide must be balanced with ecological impacts associated with the activities. Although generalizations are challenging, local scale effects of activity-specific constraints seem unlikely to be effective if other forms of water-based recreation continue.

['library(rlang)
library(metafor)
library(effsize)
library(compute.es)
library(esc)
library(meta)
library(forestplot)
library(MAd)
library(tidyr)
library(plyr)
library(dplyr)
library(splitstackshape)
library(schoolmath)
library(Gmisc)


# first set working directory
setwd("")
# - where you stored the file "Data_Meta-analysis_Schafft_etal.csv"

####load data set ####
recrfull <- read.csv("Data_Meta-analysis_Schafft_etal.csv", sep=";", header=T, dec=".")

#include only those that are definately freshwater studies
recrfull <- recrfull[(recrfull$Freshwater== 2),]

# convert variables to numeric
recrfull$Longitud <-as.numeric(gsub(",","",recrfull$Longitud,fixed=TRUE))
recrfull$C.Mean <-as.numeric(gsub(",","",recrfull$C.Mean,fixed=TRUE))
recrfull$C.neg <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$C.neg))
recrfull$C.pos <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$C.pos))
recrfull$C.N<-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$C.N))
recrfull$T.Mean <-as.numeric(gsub(",","",recrfull$T.Mean,fixed=TRUE))
recrfull$F.Test <-as.numeric(gsub(",","",recrfull$F.Test,fixed=TRUE))
recrfull$T.neg <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$T.neg))
recrfull$T.pos <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$T.pos))
recrfull$T.positive... <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$T.positive...))
recrfull$T.N<-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$T.N))
recrfull$C.SD <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$C.SD))
recrfull$C.SE <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$C.SE))
recrfull$T.SD <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$T.SD))
recrfull$T.SE <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$T.SE))
recrfull$tvalue <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$t.value))
recrfull$df <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$df))
recrfull$p.value <-as.numeric(gsub(",","",recrfull$p.value,fixed=TRUE))
recrfull$C.SE <-as.numeric(as.character(recrfull$C.SE))

rec <- recrfull
names(rec)

# exclude studies that compare different recreational activties 
#instead of comparing to control or different intensities 

rec$Real.control.............[is.na(rec$Real.control.............)]<-'999'
rec<-subset(rec, Real.control............. %in% c('1', '2', '3', '5','999'))

#### correcting direction of values ####

#first get rid of NA
rec$Meaning[is.na(rec$Meaning)]<-'1'

for(r in 1:nrow(rec)) {
  if (rec[r,43]=='2') {
    rec[r,49]<-rec[r,49]*-1;
    rec[r,53]<-rec[r,53]*-1
  } else 
    if (rec[r,43]=='3') {
      if (rec[r,42]=="+"){
        rec[r,49]<-rec[r,49]*-1;
        rec[r,53]<-rec[r,53]*-1
      }
    }
}

####calculating effect size ####

rec.sd <- rec[!is.na(rec$T.SD),]

ESg<-esc_mean_sd(grp1m = as.numeric(rec.sd$T.Mean), 
                 grp1sd = rec.sd$T.SD, 
                 grp1n = as.numeric(rec.sd$T.N),
                 grp2m =as.numeric(rec.sd$C.Mean), 
                 grp2sd = rec.sd$C.SD, 
                 grp2n = as.numeric(rec.sd$C.N),
                 es.type = "g")

rec.sd$es<-ESg$es
rec.sd$se<-ESg$var

### create colomn es and se 
### to have identical number of rows in rec and rec.sd#

rec$es<-NA
rec$se<-NA

#create the complementary to rec.sd# to be able to combine the data again 

rec.sd.t.na <- rec[is.na(rec$T.SD),]
rec<-rbind(rec.sd,rec.sd.t.na) #combine rows to have have full data set again

rec$Cohen.s.d<-NA
rec$Cohen.s.d.1<- NA

# calculate Hedges g with t-value / p-value

rec.p<- rec[!is.na(rec$p.value),]

EStg<-esc_t(t = as.numeric(rec.p$t.value), 
            p = as.numeric(rec.p$p.value), 
            grp1n = as.numeric(rec.p$T.N), 
            grp2n = as.numeric(rec.p$C.N), 
            es.type = "g")


rec.p$Cohen.s.d<-EStg$es
rec.p$Cohen.s.d.1<- EStg$var

###combine data to full data set ###
rec.p.na<- rec[is.na(rec$p.value),] #rec without rec.p
rec<-rbind(rec.p,rec.p.na) #combine rows to have have full data set again


#put values in right columns
for(r in 1:nrow(rec)) {if (is.na(rec[r,96])) {
  rec[r,96]<-rec[r,60];
  rec[r,97]<-rec[r,84] 
}
}

### calculate Odds Ratio ####

ES.OR<-escalc(measure = "OR", ai = T.pos, bi = T.neg, 
              ci = C.pos, di = C.neg, data = rec)

rec$Odds.ratio<-ES.OR$yi
rec$Risk.ratio<-ES.OR$vi


### Converting Effect Sizes ####

for(r in 1:nrow(rec)) {if (!is.na(rec[r,68])) 
  {rec[r,96]<-rec[r,68]*sqrt(3)/pi;rec[r,97]<-rec[r,69]*sqrt(3)/pi^2 }}


#### Effect size of correlations ####
r.es <- res(Correlation.coefficient......R.., var.r = NULL, sample.size, id = rec$Study_ID ,data = rec)

rec$Fishers.z <- r.es$d
rec$Variance <- r.es$var.d

# put values in right colums
for(r in 1:nrow(rec)) {if (is.na(rec[r,96])) {
  rec[r,96]<-rec[r,91];
  rec[r,97]<-rec[r,89] 
}
}

#### Effect size with F statistics ####

f.es<-fes(F.Test, T.N, C.N, 
          level = 95, 
          cer = 0.2, dig = 2, 
          verbose = TRUE, id=Study_ID, data=rec)

rec$Cohen.s.d <- f.es$g
rec$Cohen.s.d.1 <- f.es$var.g

#put values in right columns
for(r in 1:nrow(rec)) {if (is.na(rec[r,96])) {
  rec[r,96]<-rec[r,60];
  rec[r,97]<-rec[r']

Paper: Data and R code for statistical analyses on trap experiments
description: Data and R code for statistical analyses related to trap experiments used in the article titled "Attractant activity of host-related chemical blends on the Poultry Red Mite at different spatial scales".Data are provided as two .csv files and codes as one .rmd file and one .R file as follows:- 6-trap laboratory experiments (data_PRM_lab_6-trap_experiments.csv and Lab_6-trap-experiments.rmd)- field experiments (data_PRM_field_trapping.csv and Field_trap_analyses.R).
content:
['install.packages("ggplot2")
library("ggplot2")
install.packages("forcats")
library("forcats")

Field<-read.table("data_PRM_field_trapping.csv", sep=";", header=TRUE, dec=",", fill=TRUE)
# subset per period
empty<-subset(Field, period=="empty")
flock<-subset(Field, period=="flock")

# Subset per farm / empty period
DIN <- subset(empty,  FarmOK == "DIN")
DINplus <- subset(empty,  FarmOK == "DINplus")
TES <- subset(empty,  FarmOK == "TES")
SPT <- subset(empty,  FarmOK == "SPT")
FOU <- subset(empty,  FarmOK == "FOU")

# Subset per farm / flock period
flock_DIN <- subset(flock,  FarmOK == "DIN")
flock_SPT <- subset(flock,  FarmOK == "SPT")

# paired samples Wilcoxon tests
Wilc_empty_DIN <- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = DIN, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_empty_DINplus<- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = DINplus, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_empty_TES<- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = TES, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_empty_SPT<- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = SPT, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_empty_FOU<- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = FOU, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_flock_DIN <- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = flock_DIN, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_flock_SPT<- wilcox.test(no_mites ~ treatment, data = flock_SPT, paired = TRUE)
Wilc_empty_DIN
Wilc_empty_DINplus
Wilc_empty_TES
Wilc_empty_SPT
Wilc_empty_FOU
Wilc_flock_DIN 
Wilc_flock_SPT

# boxplots
empty$Farm <- fct_relevel(empty$Farm, c("DIN(n=8)", "DIN+(n=13)", "TES(n=10)", "SPT(n=10)","FOU(n=10)"))

ggplot(empty, aes(x = Farm, y = (no_mites+1), fill=treatment)) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("blue","red")) +
  scale_y_continuous(trans='log10')+
  xlab("") + ylab("Mean no of trapped mites (log-scale)") +
  theme_classic(base_size = 15)

ggplot(flock, aes(x = Farm, y = (no_mites+1), fill=treatment)) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("blue","red")) +
  scale_y_continuous(trans='log10')+
  xlab("") + ylab("Mean no of trapped mites (log-scale)") +
  theme_classic(base_size = 15)

']

Paper: Removing invasive giant reed reshapes desert riparian butterfly and bird communities
description: Giant reed (Arundo donax) is a prevalent invasive plant in desert riparian ecosystems that threatens wildlife habitat. From 2008 to 2018, under a United StatesMexico partnership, prescribed burns and herbicide applications were used to remove giant reed and promote native revegetation along the Rio Grande  Ro Bravo floodplain in west Texas, USA, and Mexico. Our goal was to explore the effects of the removal efforts on butterfly and bird communities and their habitat along the United States portion of the Rio Grande  Ro Bravo floodplain in Big Bend National Park, Texas. During spring and summer, 20162017, we surveyed butterflies, birds, and their habitat using ground-collected and remotely sensed data. Using a variety of generalized linear and N-mixture modeling routines and multivariate analyses, we found that the initial giant reed removal efforts removed key components of riparian habitat leading to reduced butterfly and bird communities. Within several years following management, giant reed levels remained low, while riparian habitat conditions and butterfly and bird communities largely rebounded, including many disturbance-sensitive butterfly species and riparian-associated bird species. Butterflies were most consistently associated with forb and grass cover, and birds with a remotely sensed index of greenness (the normalized difference vegetation index), several vegetation cover types, and habitat heterogeneity, habitat elements that were most common in locations that had the longest time to recover following management actions. Our results suggest that prescribed burns and herbicide applications, when used following protocols to minimize risk to wildlife, can limit the spread of giant reed in desert riparian systems and introduce habitat conditions that support diverse and abundant butterfly and bird communities.

["
###########  N-mixture models and model selection, birds

library(unmarked)
library(MuMIn)

# covariate data 
covs <- read.csv('visit and site covariates_allsites.csv')

# detection data, one species (specify species file)
dets <- read.csv('ISAbird_dets/BTSP_detection history.csv')

# merge and reduce to analysis sites only
Ndat <- merge(dets,covs, by='site')

grps <- read.csv('site_groups.csv')		# treatment groups
treats <- c('untreated_cane','new_treated','old_treated','reference')
grps <- grps[which(grps$treat %in% treats),]
Ndat <- Ndat[which(Ndat$site %in% grps$site),]	# subset Ndat to groups


### make unmarked data frame from Ndat
# subset different data types
	counts <- Ndat[,2:7]				# detection history
	obs.cov <- Ndat[,8:19]				# obs-level covariates
	site.cov <- Ndat[,20:27]			# site level covariates

# unmarked data frame for Royle Count model (N-mixture model)
	df <- unmarkedFramePCount(y=counts, siteCovs = site.cov, 
		obsCovs = list(obs=obs.cov[,1:6], year=obs.cov[,7:12]))
	summary(df)

# models with det covars only
	m1 <- pcount(~1~1, df, K=100) 	# model with no covariates
	m2 <- pcount(~obs~1, df, K=100) 	# models with only det covariates
	m3 <- pcount(~year ~ 1, df, K=100)		
	m4 <- pcount(~obs + year ~ 1, df, K=100)

# model selection for detection only
	mlist<-fitList(m1=m1,m2=m2,m3=m3,m4=m4)
	modSel(mlist)

### models with best det covars (see above) and adding site covariates.
### up to two site covars per model, no interactions
	# one var
	m5 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_arundo, df, K=100)	
	m6 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_woody, df, K=100)		
	m7 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_willow, df, K=100)	
	m8 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_herb, df, K=100) 
	m9 <- pcount(~obs+year~ndvi, df, K=100)
	m10 <- pcount(~obs+year~text.cv, df, K=100)
	
	# two vars
	m11 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_arundo+p_woody, df, K=100)	
	m12 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_arundo+p_willow, df, K=100)	
	m13 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_arundo+p_herb, df, K=100)
	m14 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_arundo+ndvi, df, K=100)
	m15 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_arundo+text.cv, df, K=100)
	m16 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_woody+p_willow, df, K=100)		
	m17 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_woody+p_herb, df, K=100)	
	m18 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_willow+p_herb, df, K=100) 
	m19 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_willow+ndvi, df, K=100) 
	m20 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_willow+text.cv, df, K=100) 
	m21 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_herb+ndvi, df, K=100) 
	m22 <- pcount(~obs+year~p_herb+text.cv, df, K=100) 
	m23 <- pcount(~obs+year~ndvi+text.cv, df, K=100)

# model selection. note m4 is 'null', i.e., no site covars.	
seltab <- model.sel(m4,m5,m6,m7,m8,m9,m10,m11,
	m12,m13,m14,m15,m16,m17,m18,m19,m20,m21,m22,m23)
seltab

## variable importance, across models
importance(seltab)




", '
### BUTTERFLY GLM models and model selection  ###

library(MASS)
library(MuMIn)

# butterfly abundances
bydat <- read.csv("Butterfly_rel_abun.csv")

# subset to indicator species
i.s <- c('PACR','LAOS','SLOR','FAME','QUEE','REBL')
is.idx <- which(names(bydat) %in% i.s)
bydat <- bydat[,c(1,is.idx)]

# veg data 
vegdat <- read.csv('VEGandRSdata_73 analysis sites.csv')

# merge species abundances and habitat data
dat <- merge(vegdat,bydat, by='site')

### negative binomial GLMs

# choose species from i.s (e.g., PACR)
sp <- i.s[6]
dat$spec <- dat[,which(names(dat)==sp)]

## model set -- up to two covariates, no interactions
	# one var
	m1 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))	
	m2 <- glm.nb(spec~p_woody, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))		
	m3 <- glm.nb(spec~p_willow, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))	
	m4 <- glm.nb(spec~herb.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m5 <- glm.nb(spec~grass.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))
	m6 <- glm.nb(spec~ndvi, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))
	m7 <- glm.nb(spec~text.cv, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))
	# two vars
	m8 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo+p_woody, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))	
	m9 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo+p_willow, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=25))	
	m10 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo+herb.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))
	m11 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo+grass.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))
	m12 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo+ndvi, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))
	m13 <- glm.nb(spec~p_arundo+text.cv, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=25))

	m14 <- glm.nb(spec~p_woody+p_willow, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=25))		
	m15 <- glm.nb(spec~p_woody+herb.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))	
	m16 <- glm.nb(spec~p_woody+grass.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))	

	m17 <- glm.nb(spec~p_willow+herb.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m18 <- glm.nb(spec~p_willow+grass.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m19 <- glm.nb(spec~p_willow+ndvi, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=25)) 
	m20 <- glm.nb(spec~p_willow+text.cv, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=75)) 
	
	m21 <- glm.nb(spec~herb.t+grass.t, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m22 <- glm.nb(spec~herb.t+ndvi, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m23 <- glm.nb(spec~herb.t+text.cv, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 

	m24 <- glm.nb(spec~grass.t+ndvi, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m25 <- glm.nb(spec~grass.t+text.cv, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50)) 
	m26 <- glm.nb(spec~ndvi+text.cv, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=25))

	# 'null' model (no habitat covariates)
	m.nul <- glm.nb(spec~1, dat, control=glm.control(maxit=50))

# model selection
seltab <- model.sel(m.nul,m1,m2,m3,m4,m5,m6,m7,m8,m9,m10,m11,
	m12,m13,m14,m15,m16,m17,m18,m19,m20,m21,m22,m23,
	m24,m25,m26)
seltab

## variable importance, across models
importance(seltab)



', '########## look at bird/butterfly rio grande data files

library(vegan)
library(pairwiseAdonis)
library(indicspecies)


#### BIRDS ####

# bird data
dat2 <- read.csv('Bird_abun_Nmixture.csv')

## bray-curtis dissimilarity
bcdist <- vegdist(dat2[,4:26])		
hist(bcdist, breaks=40, col='gray')
### There is a good dstn of dissimilarity values.

# NMDS
birdord <- metaMDS(dat2[,4:26], k=3, trymax=1000)	
stressplot(birdord)
birdord

# indicator species analysis (ISA)
sp <- dat2[,4:26]		#species 
ind <- multipatt(sp, dat2$grp, func='r', 	#'r' for abun data
	control = how(nperm=9999)) 		#perumations
summary(ind, alpha=0.10)
ind$sign


# test for group differences (permanova)
grp.sim <- adonis2(dat2[,4:26] ~ as.factor(dat2$grp), permutations = 9999, distance = 'bray')
grp.sim
# evidence for some differences

# post-hoc pairwise tests
grp.pw <- pairwise.adonis(dat2[,4:26], dat2$treat, sim.method = 'bray', perm=9999)
grp.pw
# there are multiple group differences

# betadisper: test for differences in dispersion among groups, birds
mod <- betadisper(bcdist, dat2$grp, type='centroid',add=TRUE)
mod
plot(mod)
# permutation test for F
per <- permutest(mod, pairwise = TRUE, permutations = 9999)
per
# Tukey's Honest Significant Differences
mod.HSD <- TukeyHSD(mod)
plot(mod.HSD)
# no difference among groups in dispersion.


# plot NMDS results, birds
# colors with transparency
## RGB values for named color
rgb.1 <- col2rgb('black')
rgb.2 <- col2rgb('orange')
rgb.3 <- col2rgb('blue')
rgb.4 <- col2rgb('red')

# with transparency
col.1 <- rgb(rgb.1[1], rgb.1[2], rgb.1[3], max = 255, alpha = 150)
col.2 <- rgb(rgb.2[1], rgb.2[2], rgb.2[3], max = 255, alpha = 150)
col.3 <- rgb(rgb.3[1], rgb.3[2], rgb.3[3], max = 255, alpha = 150)
col.4 <- rgb(rgb.4[1], rgb.4[2], rgb.4[3], max = 255, alpha = 150)

grps.tran <- c(col.1,col.2,col.3,col.4)

# without transparency
colgrps <- c("black", "orange", "blue", "red")

## export plot
filename <- "bird abun NMDS_polys.tiff"
tiff(filename, width = 4, height = 4.5, units='in', res=1200, compression="lzw")	#open tiff render
	
	plot(birdord$points, xlim=c(-0.26,0.32), ylim=c(-0.23,0.32), type='n',
		axes=F, frame=F)
	axis(1, tck= -0.02, padj= -2.2, hadj=0.65, las=1, cex.axis=0.65)	# x-axis
	axis(2, tck= -0.02, mgp=c(1,0.5,0), las=1, cex.axis=0.65)		# y-axis
	points(birdord, display='sites', pch=16, cex=0.7, col=grps.tran[dat2$grp])
	ordiellipse(birdord, dat2$grp, col=colgrps, kind='sd', draw='polygon', alpha=100, border='transparent')
	ordiellipse(birdord, dat2$grp, col=colgrps, kind='se', draw='polygon', alpha=100, border='transparent')

dev.off()			# close tiff render




#### BUTTERFLIES  ####

# data file
dat2 <- read.csv("Butterfly_rel_abun.csv")

## look at bray-curtis dissimilarity
bcdist <- vegdist(dat2[,4:24])		
hist(bcdist, breaks=40, col='gray')
## There is a good dstn of dissimilarity values.

# NMDS
byord <- metaMDS(dat2[,4:24], k=3, trymax=1000)	
stressplot(byord)
byord

# indicator species analysis (ISA)
sp <- dat2[,4:24]
ind <- multipatt(sp, dat2$grp, func='r', control = how(nperm=9999)) 
summary(ind, alpha=0.1)
ind$sign


## test for group differences, butterflies
grp.sim <- adonis2(dat2[,4:24] ~ as.factor(dat2$grp), permutations = 9999, distance = 'bray')
grp.sim
# there is evidence for differences

# post-hoc pairwise tests
grp.pw <- pairwise.adonis(dat2[,4:24], dat2$treat, sim.method = 'bray', perm=9999)
grp.pw
# there are several group differences, with weaker evidence than birds

# differences in dispersion among groups (betadisper), butterflies
mod <- betadisper(bcdist, dat2$grp, type='centroid', add=TRUE)
mod
plot(mod)
# permutation test for F
permutest(mod, pairwise = TRUE, permutations = 9999)
# Tukey's Honest Significant Differences
mod.HSD <- TukeyHSD(mod)
plot(mod.HSD)
# possibly weak evidence for some differences among
# groups in dispersion, but no single group-group difference
# with strong evidence.


# plot NMDS results, butterflies
## export plot
filename <- "butterfly abun NMDS_polys.tiff"
tiff(filename, width = 4, height = 4.5, units='in', res=1200, compression="lzw")	#open tiff render

keywords: giant reed, invasive plant, desert riparian ecosystem, wildlife habitat, prescribed burns, herbicide applications, United States-Mexico partnership, native revegetation, Rio Grande/Ro Bravo floodplain, west Texas, butterfly communities, bird

Paper: Data from: Does pollen limitation limit plant ranges? Evidence and implications
description: Sexual reproduction often declines towards range edges, reducing fitness, dispersal, and adaptive potential at range edges. For plants, sexual reproduction is frequently limited by inadequate pollination. While case studies show that pollen limitation can limit plant distributions, the extent to which pollination commonly declines toward plant range edges is unknown. Here, we leverage global databases of pollen-supplementation experiments and plant occurrence data to test whether pollen limitation increases toward plant range edges, using a phylogenetically controlled meta-analysis. While there was significant pollen limitation across studies, we found little evidence that pollen limitation increases toward plant range edges. Pollen limitation was not stronger toward the tropics, nor at species' equatorward vs poleward range limits. Meta-analysis results are consistent with results from targeted experiments, in which pollen limitation increased significantly toward only 14% of 14 plant range edges, suggesting that pollination contributes to range limits less often than do other interactions. Together, these results suggest pollination is one of the rich variety of potential ecological factors that can contribute to range limits, rather than a generally important constraint on plant distributions.

['##Dawson-Glass: Does pollen limitation limit plant ranges? Evidence and implications 2021 manuscript submission
##GloPL dataset cleaning and GBIF download for all species

##

# LOAD PACKAGES ###############################################################

#In this script, variables used:
###Species_accepted_names: correct name of species as determined by the GloPL authors
    #NB, Species_accepted_names must be cleaned to only species level, not including varieties or subspecies (done in this script)
###Latitude and Longitude: self explanatory, corresponding lat long of each study point
###occurrence_no: unique occurrence number for each entry in the GloPL dataset, that will be used in later loops to make sure all data matches up and
  #simplifies editing. NB below we create the "Master" GloPL dataset with occurrence nos, which we will use for the remainder of all code (will not change or update occurrence no again) 

# Load master GloPL dataset (RUN THIS CODE ONCE - then skip to L47)
GloPL.orig <-read.csv("GloPL_04_20/GloPL_Download_04_24_20/GloPL.csv")
 # add a unique occurrence number for each entry to ease data cleaning and editing
GloPL.orig$occurrence_no <- 1:nrow(GloPL.orig)
# #Save as the master dataset you will be referencing from now on
write.csv(GloPL.orig, "GloPL_04_20/GloPL_Download_04_24_20/GloPL_MASTER_occ_no.csv")
# ###########

# PREP GLOPL DATA #########################################################
#Starting with GloPL dataset with occurrence numbers
GloPL <- read.csv("GloPL_04_20/GloPL_Download_04_24_20/GloPL_MASTER_occ_no.csv", stringsAsFactors =T)
GloPL$X <- NULL
summary(GloPL)

#How many species do we start with?
og_no_sps <- as.data.frame(unique(GloPL$Species_accepted_names))
dim(og_no_sps)
#starting with 1265 species--including varieties and subspecies (consistent with GloPL publication: "1265 wild plant species across the globe")

#we don't want to model variety/subsp range- only the species generally, so we create a new column with only species name (not including
#var or subsp)

#Save original species name in a new column-- will need it later
GloPL$SpeciesGloPLNames <- GloPL$Species_accepted_names

#modify species name to be the full species name without variety or subspecies, as there is not enough data in GBIF to create range for these
#this old code was deleting anything with the phrase var in it, replacing with more inclusive code
#GloPL$Species_accepted_names<-sub("_var._*", "", GloPL$Species_accepted_names)

#delete subspecies  (ok, doesn't delete anything incorrectly)
subsp <- GloPL[grepl("subsp.", GloPL[["Species_accepted_names"]]), ]
unique(subsp$Species_accepted_names)
#you should have 22 subsp
#Remove the subspecies naming info from column
GloPL$Species_accepted_names <- sub("_subsp.*", "", GloPL$Species_accepted_names)

#delete variety from species names
varieties <- GloPL[grepl("var._", GloPL[["Species_accepted_names"]]), ]
unique(varieties$Species_accepted_names)
#should have 17 species with a  variety
#delete var.... from species name
varieties$Species_accepted_names<-sub("_var.*", "", varieties$Species_accepted_names)
#subset out only the name and occurrence no
varieties<-varieties %>%
  select(Species_accepted_names, occurrence_no)
#using loop (there is probably a better way to do this but this is the way I know how to do and it works)
#match the edited names with the master occurrence no in the GloPL dataset to have corrected name in species accepted name column
for (j in 1:nrow(varieties))
{	cat(j, "out of", nrow(varieties), "at", date(), varieties$occurrence_no[j], "\n")
  {
    GloPL$Species_accepted_names[GloPL$occurrence_no==varieties$occurrence_no[j]] = varieties$Species_accepted_names[j]
}}

#How many species do we have now?
num_sps_no_v.sbs <- as.data.frame(unique(GloPL$Species_accepted_names))
dim(num_sps_no_v.sbs) #Sho', '##Dawson-Glass: Does pollen limitation limit plant ranges? Evidence and implications 2021 
##Map generation and measurements for target species in GloPL

#This is the 2nd of 3 R scripts for the "Where and how often does pollen limitation limit species range distributions" project
#This script generates a range map using species occurrences downloaded in the RGBIF script and measures range distances, among other variables needed for analysis

# LOAD PACKAGES ##############################################################

#This is the statistical analysis script for  "Does pollen limitation limit plant ranges? Evidence and implications"

#occurrence_no: unique number for each row of data
#Species_accepted_names: name of study species, as correctly determined by original GloPL authors, EXCLUDING subspecies and varieties 
#SpeciesGloPLNames: Full species name listed in original GloPL database, including subspecies and varieties, (necessary to match with phylogenetic matrix)
#PL_Effect_Size: log response ratio pollen limitation effect size, calculated in the original GLoPL database
#Sampling_variance: sampling variance of the pollen limitation effect size, as calculated in script R1, based on equations from Gurevitch et al., 2001

#Cleaning GBIF occ

  dplyr::select(species, decimalLongitude, decimalLatitude, countryCode,
                gbifID, family, taxonRank, year,
                basisOfRecord, institutionCode, datasetName)#reduce many columns in GBIF occurance file to a few relevant ones
gbifocc <- gbifocc%>%
  filter(!is.na(decimalLongitude))%>%
  filter(!is.na(decimalLatitude))#get rid of NA values
#change country code system to iso3c
gbifocc$countryCode <-  countrycode(gbifocc$countryCode, origin =  'iso2c', destination = 'iso3c')
# remove zeroes
if (any(gbifocc$decimalLongitude == 0 | gbifocc$decimalLatitude == 0, na.rm = TRUE))
{gbifocc <- gbifocc[-which(gbifocc$decimalLongitude == 0 | gbifocc$decimalLatitude == 0), ]
}
gbifocc <- data.frame(gbifocc)
# Remove duplicate records (remove if not desired, can greatly reduce number of observations)
if (nrow(gbifocc) >= 1)  #ie ignore header row 
  #SpatialPoints creates object of class SpatialPoints (from sp package)
{spgeo <- SpatialPoints(data.frame(lon = gbifocc$decimalLongitude, lat = gbifocc$decimalLatitude)) 
zd <- zerodist(spgeo) #zerodist finds point pairs with equal spatial coordinates
if (length(zd) > 0) #ie if found any duplicates
{spgeo <- spgeo[-zd[, 2], ] #spgeo df without anything in the second column of zd (1st column of z gives 1st occurrence, 2nd column of z gives the duplicate row)

}}
#

#occuring at the GBIF headquarters, etc (see) ?clean_coordinates() for full details
flags <- clean_coordinates(x = gbifocc, lon = "decimalLongitude", lat = "decimalLatitude",

GloPL_big_gbif$Species_accepted_names[GloPL_big_gbif$Species_accepted_names=="Acacia_dealbata_Af"] = "Acacia_dealbata"
