      GBIFocc <- read.csv(file = paste("/Volumes/2020HAR/Species_occurrence_Gbif.nosync/", sps_in_data$Species_accepted_names[i], ".csv", sep = ""))
      key_info<-count(GBIFocc, "datasetKey")#get unique keys used
      key_info$Species<-sps_in_data$Species_accepted_names[i]
      
      Data_key_GloPL<-rbind(Data_key_GloPL, key_info)#just keep pasting on to the end of the created dataset
    }, error=function(e){cat("ERROR :",conditionMessage(e), "\n")}) #Keeps loop running even if there's an error
}
#delete test variable
Data_key_GloPL_final<-subset(Data_key_GloPL, !(Species %in% "test"))
#count how many species there are (552)
unique(Data_key_GloPL_final$Species)
#verify all species accounted for
test<-subset(sps_in_data, !(Species_accepted_names %in% Data_key_GloPL_final$Species))
#reorder so species is first
names(Data_key_GloPL_final)
Data_key_GloPL_final<-Data_key_GloPL_final[, c("Species", "datasetKey", "freq")]
#save file 
write.csv(Data_key_GloPL_final, "Poll_lim_phil_trans_GBIF_dataKey_21_09_05.csv")
']
keywords: pollen limitation, plant ranges, sexual reproduction, fitness, dispersal, adaptive potential, inadequate pollination, case studies, plant distributions, global databases, pollen-supplementation experiments, plant occurrence data, phylogenetically controlled meta-analysis, tropics,

Paper: Competition and co-association, but not phosphorous availability, shape the benefits of phosphate solubilising root bacteria for maize (Zea mays).
description: Predicting the conditions under which rhizobacteria benefit plant growth remains challenging. Here we tested the hypothesis that benefits from inoculation with phosphate-solubilising rhizobacteria will depend upon two environmental conditions: phosphate availability and competition between bacteria. Maize-associated rhizobacteria with varying phosphate solubilisation ability were used in experiments in soil, sterilised soil and gnotobiotic microcosms under conditions of varying orthophosphate availability, while we manipulated intensity of competition by varying the number of isolates in plant inocula. Growth promotion by microbes did not depend on phosphate availability but was affected by interactions between inoculants: beneficial effects of one Serratia isolate were detectable only when plants were inoculated with a single strain and beneficial effects of a competition sensitive Rhizobium was only detectable in sterilised soil or in microcosms inoculated with single strains. Moreover, microcosm experiments suggested that facilitation of a parasitic isolate, not competitive interactions between bacteria, prevented plants from gaining benefits from a potential mutualist. Competition and facilitation affected colonization of plants in microcosms but growth promotion by Serratia was more affected by inoculation treatment than culturable densities on roots. Experimental manipulation of seed inocula can reveal whether plant growth stimulation is robust with respect to competition, as well as the ecological strategies of different rhizobacteria. From an applied perspective, phosphate solubilisation may not provide the mechanism for bacterial growth promotion but may indicate mutualistic potential due to phylogenetic associations. Importantly, benefits to plants are vulnerable to interactions between rhizobacteria and may not persist in mixed inoculations.

['# R script to look at CFUs for PSB project
# Get the path to current open R script and find main dir

setwd("~/Dropbox/Andy M/Shared with BEN/Phosphate manuscript/PHOSPHATE DATA JO")
rm( list = ls( ) )
if(!require(rstudioapi)){install.packages('rstudioapi')}
library( rstudioapi ) 
path_to_file <- getActiveDocumentContext()$path
wd <- paste( dirname( path_to_file ), "/", sep = "" )
setwd( wd )

# load packages with pacman
if(!require(pacman)){install.packages('pacman')}
library(pacman)
pacman::p_load(corrplot,cowplot,forcats,ggplot2,MASS,viridisLite)

#read'em back in after painful cleaning

cfu_trt<-read.table("cfu_by_trt_no_pseudo.txt",header = TRUE)
head(cfu_trt)
cfu_no_fungi<-cfu_trt[cfu_trt$Fungal=="Not",]
head(cfu_no_fungi)
cfu_simp<-cfu_no_fungi[cfu_no_fungi$t2=="one"|cfu_no_fungi$t2=="CONTROL",]
head(cfu_simp)
cfu_no_W<-cfu_no_fungi[cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="CONTROL"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="X"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="XY"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="XYZ"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="XZ"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="YZ"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="Z"|cfu_no_fungi$Treatment=="Y",]
head(cfu_no_W)
cfu_nofu_nomul<-cfu_no_fungi[cfu_no_fungi$Treatment!="MULTI",]
cfu_nomulti<-cfu_trt[cfu_trt$Treatment!="MULTI",]

community <- cfu_nomulti[,1:4]

colnames(community) <- c('Y','X','W','Z') # correct names now

# set up some vectors for the loops
p_vec <- vector()
chi_vec <- vector()
chi_matrix_list <- list()
combo_counter <- 0

# run over the community column names to make pairs of strains (i and j)
for(i in 1:length(colnames(community))){
  for(j in 1:length(colnames(community))){
    
    # only run if not comparing a strain with itself and avoid running a pair twice
    if(i != j & i < j){
      combo_counter <- combo_counter + 1 # count what number pairing this is
      # set counts to 0
      n_i <- 0
      n_j <- 0
      n_ij <- 0
      n_none <- 0
      
      # count the rows with presence absence combos
      for(row in 1:length(community[,i])){ 
        if(community[row,i]>0 & community[row,j]==0){
          n_i <- n_i + 1
        } else if(community[row,i]==0 & community[row,j]>0){
          n_j <- n_j + 1
        } else if(community[row,i]>0 & community[row,j]>0){
          n_ij <- n_ij + 1
        } else if(community[row,i]==0 & community[row,j]==0){
          n_none <- n_none + 1
        }
      }
      
      # run chi square tests, pull out p value and test statistic into two vectors 'p_vec' 'chi_vec' respectively, and name the vector elements according to the combo of strains
      chi_mat <- matrix(c(n_ij,n_j,n_i,n_none), nrow = 2)
      p_vec[combo_counter] <- chisq.test(chi_mat)$p.value
      if(length(p_vec)==1){
        names(p_vec) <- c(names(p_vec),paste(colnames(community)[i],colnames(community)[j],sep = "*"))
      } else {
        names(p_vec) <- c(names(p_vec)[1:length(p_vec)-1],paste(colnames(community)[i],colnames(community)[j],sep = "*"))
      }
      chi_vec[combo_counter] <- chisq.test(chi_mat)$statistic
      names(chi_vec) <- names(p_vec)
      
      # name the matrix columns and rows and save as a list so we can view them 
      colnames(chi_mat) <- c(paste(colnames(community)[j],'present',sep = "_"),
                             paste(colnames(community)[j],'absent',sep = "_"))
      rownames(chi_mat) <- c(paste(colnames(community)[i],'present',sep = "_"),
                             paste(colnames(community)[i],'absent',sep = "_"))
      chi_matrix_list[[combo_counter]] <- chi_mat
      names(chi_matrix_list) <- names(chi_vec)
    }
  }
}

# use FDR correction on p values for multiple testing (NB not sure what method is used in microbiology, I use FDR in my gene expression work)
p_adjust_vec <- p.adjust(p_vec, method = 'fdr', n = length(p_vec))
chi_matrix_list
p_adjust_vec
chi_vec

#BR graphical exploration

w1<-ggplot(data=cfu_nomulti, aes(x=Treatment, y=(mean_w+1)))+
geom_boxplot()+scale_y_log10(name="Isolate W CFU / ml")+guides(x = guide_axis(angle = -45))
w1
y1<-ggplot(data=cfu_nomulti, aes(x=Treatment, y=(mean_y+1)))+
  geom_boxplot()+scale_y_log10(name="Isolate Z CFU / ml")+guides(x = guide_axis(angle = -45))
y1
x1<-ggplot(data=cfu_nomulti, aes(x=Treatment, y=(mean_x+1)))+
  geom_boxplot()+scale_y_log10(name="Isolate Y CFU / ml")+guides(x = guide_axis(angle = -45))
x1
sw1<-ggplot(data=cfu_nomulti, aes(x=Treatment, y=(mean_swd+1)))+
  geom_boxplot()+scale_y_log10(name="Isolate X CFU / ml ")+guides(x = guide_axis(angle = -45))
sw1

library(cowplot)
#all the boxplots
raw_cfu<-plot_grid(w1,y1,x1,sw1,ncol = 2)
raw_cfu


#simplify competition treatments to number of competitors in inoculum
cfu_trt$t2<-as.factor(cfu_trt$Treatment)
levels(cfu_trt$t2)
levels(cfu_trt$t2)[6]<-"many"

Paper: Code + simulated + publically accessable data for "Evaluating health facility access using Bayesian spatial models and location analysis methods"
description: # READMEThese files contain r data objects and R files that represent the key details of the paper, "Evaluating health facility access using Bayesian spatial models and location analysis methods".The following datasources are available for simulation of some of the ideas in the paper.- dat_grid_sim: simulated data of the grid and grid cells- dat_ohca_cv_sim: simulated data containing the cross validated test/training sets of OHCA data- dat_ohca_sim: simulated OHCA event data- dat_aed_sim: simulated AED location data- dat_bldg_sim: simulated building location data- dat_municipality_sim: simulated municipality information- table_1: Table 1 information containing key demographic dataThese data were produced using the code in 01-create-sim-data.R, and one of the statistical models is demonstrated in 02-demo-inla-model.RIn terms of the paper itself, the functions and code used in the manuscript are located in:* 01_tidy.Rmd - analysis code used to tidy up the data* 02_fit_fixed_all_cv.Rmd - analysis code used to place AEDs* 02_model.Rmd - analysis code used to fit the model in INLA* 03_manuscript.Rmd - Full code and text used to create the paper* 04_supp_materials.Rmd - full code and text used to create the supplementary materialsThe following files are a part of an R package "swatial" that was developed along with the paper. These files are:* DESCRIPTION* NAMESPACE* LICENSE* LICENSE.md* decay.R* spherical-distance.R* test-figure-data-matches.R* test-table-data-matches.R* testthat.R* tidy-inla.R* tidy-posterior-coefs.R* tidy-predictions.R* utils-pipe.R* All files that end in .Rd are documentation files for the functions.## Regarding data sourcesCensus information for Ticino was transcribed from the Annual Statistical Report of Canton Ticino from years 2010 to 2015. This data was taken from their publicly accessible annual reports - for example: (https://www3.ti.ch/DFE/DR/USTAT/allegati/volume/ast_2015.pdf). The raw data was extracted from these annual reports, and placed into the file: "swiss_census_popn_2010_2015.xlsx". These data are put into analysis ready format in the file 01_tidy.RmdHousing and other relevant geospatial data can be accessed via http://map.housing-stat.ch/ and https://data.geo.admin.ch/. The maps of buildings from the REA (Register of Buildings and Dwellings) can be found here: https://map.geo.admin.ch/?zoom=11&bgLayer=ch.swisstopo.pixelkarte-grau&lang=en&topic=ech&layers=ch.bfs.gebaeude_wohnungs_register,ch.swisstopo.swissboundaries3d-gemeinde-flaeche.fill,ch.bfs.volkszaehlung-gebaeudestatistik_gebaeude,ch.bfs.volkszaehlung-gebaeudestatistik_wohnungen,ch.swisstopo.swissbuildings3d_1.metadata,ch.swisstopo.swissbuildings3d_2.metadata&E=2717616.28&N=1096597.25&catalogNodes=687,696&layers_timestamp=,,2016,2016,,&layers_visibility=true,false,false,false,false,false&layers_opacity=1,1,1,1,1,0.75For further enquiries on this data, contact the Swiss federal Office of Statistics at the details listed here: https://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/en/home/services/contact.htmlThe shapefiles of the Comuni can be accessed here: https://www4.ti.ch/dfe/de/ucr/documentazione/download-file/?noMobile=1Data from the people living in the Municipalities in Ticino can be downloaded here: https://www3.ti.ch/DFE/DR/USTAT/index.php?fuseaction=dati.home&tema=33&id2=61&id3=65&c1=01&c2=02&c3=02## Future workIn the future, these functions from the paper may be generalised and put into their own package. If that happens, this repository will be updated with a link to updated functions.

['# simulate the data for the swiss spatial paper ""
# Author: Nicholas Tierney

# R packages used: sf, tidyverse, here
library(sf)
library(tidyverse)

grid_sim_prep <-
  readr::read_rds(
here::here("manuscript/outputs/01_tidy_output/rpolycount.rds")
    ) %>%
  st_as_sf() %>%
  rename(pop_dens = `Density_per_km2`,
         prop_men = `1002_02_Pop Men_Perc`,
         prop_65 = `1010_02_Pop 65 years and above_Perc`,
         prop_transport = `01_Set_Urb_03_Transport`,
         prop_industr_comm = `01_Set_Urb_01_IndComm`,
         prop_bldg = `01_Set_Urb_02_Building`,
         prop_rec = `01_Set_Urb_05_RecrCem`,
         prop_spec_urb = `01_Set_Urb_04_Special`,
         prop_finance = `1050_01_Financial strength index_Value`) %>%
  mutate(prop_transport = prop_transport/area_hectare,
         prop_industr_comm = prop_industr_comm/area_hectare,
         prop_bldg = prop_bldg/area_hectare,
         prop_rec = prop_rec/area_hectare,
         prop_spec_urb = prop_spec_urb/area_hectare) %>% 
  mutate(prop_transport = prop_transport/n_grid,
         prop_industr_comm = prop_industr_comm/n_grid,
         prop_bldg = prop_bldg/n_grid,
         prop_rec = prop_rec/n_grid,
         prop_spec_urb = prop_spec_urb/n_grid,
         pop_dens = pop_dens / n_grid,
         prop_men = prop_men / n_grid,
         prop_65 = prop_65 / n_grid,
         prop_finance = prop_finance / n_grid) %>%
  select(count,
         prop_men,
         pop_dens,
         prop_65,
         prop_transport,
         prop_industr_comm,
         prop_bldg,
         prop_rec,
         prop_spec_urb,
         prop_finance)

# simulation: find min and max, generate values between them uniformly.

dat_grid_sim <- grid_sim_prep %>%
  dplyr::transmute_if(.predicate = is.numeric,
                      .funs = function(x){
                        runif(n = x, min = min(x), max = max(x))
                        }) %>%
  mutate(count = round(count))

# make this an sp object.
dat_grid_sim <- as(dat_grid_sim, "Spatial")

# write the data

# Author: Nicholas Tierney

# Packages used: spdep, INLA.

library(INLA)

bsa_adj_swiss <- spdep::poly2nb(dat_grid_sim_sp, queen = FALSE)

adj_swiss <- spdep::nb2mat(bsa_adj_swiss,
                           style = "B",
                           zero.policy = TRUE) %>% as("dgTMatrix")

swiss_idx <- 1:nrow(dat_grid_sim_sp)

btdf <- as.data.frame(dat_grid_sim_sp) 

system.time(
  model_inla_bym_grid <- 
    inla(formula = 
           count ~ prop_men +

           prop_transport +

           prop_rec +

           f(swiss_idx,

         family = "zeroinflatedpoisson1",

                                config = TRUE, # to calculate posterior draws
                                cpo = TRUE), 
         control.predictor = list(compute = TRUE,
                                  link = 1))
)

# took me about 300 seconds to fit the model', '#' Gaussian Decay function
#' 
#' This is a function that creates some decay between some distance and the 
#' maximum distance.
#'
#' @param d_kj given distance
#' @param d_0 maximum distance. When d_kj == d_0, you will get 0
#'
#' @return numeric
#' 
#' @export
#'
#' @examples
#' 
#' gauss_decay(1,100)
#' gauss_decay(50,100)
#' gauss_decay(99,100)
#' 
gauss_decay <- function(d_kj, 
                        d_0) {
  if (d_kj <= d_0) {
    (exp(-0.5 * (d_kj / d_0) ^ 2)
     - exp(-0.5)) / (1 - exp(-0.5))
  } else 0
  # warning("d_0 should not be greater than d_kj")
}

# A note here that the input for d_kj is all of those OHCA events that are 
# within 100m of the given AED / EMS location
# So this means that there will be some really cool function
# that will use the distance calculation between the AEDs and OHCA
# (grab from maxcovr)


#' Stepwise decay function
#'
#' @param d_kj given distance
#' @param d_0 maximum distance. When d_kj == d_0, you will get 0
#' @param jump specified jump distance - default of 0.09
#' @param n_steps The number of steps to include, default is 5
#'
#' @return single numeric number of the decay value
#' @export
#'
#' @examples
#' step_decay(0, 100)
#' step_decay(1, 100)
#' step_decay(50, 100)
#' step_decay(99, 100)
#' step_decay(100, 100)
step_decay <- function(d_kj,
                       d_0,
                       jump = 0.09,
                       n_steps = 5) {
  
  steps <- 1 - jump * 1:n_steps
  
  size  <- 1 / n_steps
  
  out <- ifelse(test = (d_kj <= d_0),
                yes = steps[floor(d_kj / d_0 / size) + 1],
                no = 0)
  
  out[is.na(out)] <- 0
  
  return(out)
  
}
', "#' Calculate the distance between two lat/lon
#'
#' This function uses the haversine formula to calculate the great circle
#' distance between two locations, identified by their latitudes and 
#' longitudes. It is borrowed from rnoaa
#' (https://github.com/ropenscilabs/rnoaa/blob/master/R/meteo_distance.R) 
#' I have renamed it from meteo_spherical_distance to spherical_distance
#'
#' @param lat1 Latitude of the first location.
#' @param long1 Longitude of the first location.
#' @param lat2 Latitude of the second location.
#' @param long2 Longitude of the second location.
#'
#' @return A numeric value giving the distance in meters between the
#'    pair of locations.
#'
#' @note This function assumes an earth radius of 6,371 km.
#'
#' @examples
#'
#' spherical_distance(lat1 = -27.4667,
#'                    long1 = 153.0217,
#'                    lat2 = -27.4710,
#'                    long2 = 153.0234)
#'
#' @export
spherical_distance <- function(lat1,
                               long1,
                               lat2,
                               long2) {
  
  radius_earth <- 6371
  
  deg2rad <- function(deg) return(deg*pi/180)
  # Convert angle values into radians
  lat1 <- deg2rad(lat1)
  long1 <- deg2rad(long1)
  lat2 <- deg2rad(lat2)
  long2 <- deg2rad(long2)
  
  # Determine distance using the haversine formula, assuming a spherical earth
  a <- sin((lat2 - lat1) / 2) ^ 2 + cos(lat1) * cos(lat2) *
    sin((long2 - long1) / 2) ^ 2
  
  d <- 2 * atan2(sqrt(a), sqrt(1 - a)) * radius_earth
  
  # return distance in kilometres
  d <- d * 1000
  # return(d)
  # return the distance in kilometers
  return(d)
  
} # End function", 'context("Figure data")

', '#' Tidy up INLA model output
#'
#' @param x an INLA model
#'
#' @return a dataframe with columns "terms" "mean" "sd" "0.025quant" "0.5quant" "0.975quant" "mode" "kld"
#' 
#' @export
#'
#' @examples
#' 
#' \dontrun{
#' 
#' tidy(model_inla_bym_grid)
#' 
#' }
#' 
tidy.inla <- function(x){
  
  tibble::as_tibble(x$summary.fixed) %>%
    dplyr::mutate(terms = rownames(.)) %>%
    dplyr::select(terms,
                  dplyr::everything())
  
}', '#' Tidy INLA Posterior Coefficients
#'
#' Creates a dataframe where each row is a posterior sample, and the 
#' columns are the coefficients from the model. Still need to work out how
#' to get the inla
#'
#' @param samples 
#' @param model 
#'
#' @return dataframe of posterior coefficients
#' @export
#'
#' @examples
#' 
#' \dontrun{
#' tidy_posterior_coefs(inla_bym_samples,model_inla_bym_grid)
#' }
#' 
tidy_posterior_coefs <- function(samples, 
                                 model, 
                                 new_covars = TRUE){
  
  latent_rows <- rownames(samples[[1]]$latent)
  coef_in_samples_lgl <- latent_rows %in% model$names.fixed
  coef_names_in_samples <- latent_rows[coef_in_samples_lgl]
  
  coef_names_in_samples
  
  if (new_covars == TRUE) {
    
    test_inla_sample <- samples %>%
      purrr::map_dfr(
        .f = function(x){
          tibble::tibble("(Intercept)" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][1],
                 "prop_men" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][2],
                 "pop_dens" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][3],
                 "prop_65" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][4],
                 "prop_transport" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][5],
                 "prop_industr_comm" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][6],
                 "prop_bldg" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][7],
                 "prop_rec" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][8],
                 "prop_spec_urb" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][9],
                 "prop_finance" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][10])
        }
      )
    
  } else if (new_covars == FALSE) {
    test_inla_sample <- samples %>%
      purrr::map_dfr(
        .f = function(x){
          tibble::tibble("(Intercept)" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][1],
                 "prop_65_and_up" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][2],
                 "prop_male" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][3],
                 "population_density" = x$latent[coef_in_samples_lgl][4])
        }
      )
  }
  return(test_inla_sample)
  
} # end function', "#' Tidy up the predictions from an INLA model
#' 
#' Create a dataframe of the predictions
#'
#' @param x 
#'
#' @return data.frame
#' 
#' @export
#'
#' @examples
#' 
#' \dontrun{
#' tidy_predictions(model_inla_bym_grid)
#' }
tidy_predictions <- function(x){
  
  tibble::as_tibble(x$summary.linear.predictor) %>%
    dplyr::mutate(terms = rownames(.)) %>%
    dplyr::mutate(predictor_id = readr::parse_number(terms)) %>%
    dplyr::select(
      predictor_id,
      dplyr::everything()
    )
  
}", "#' Pipe operator
#'

#'

NULL

generics::tidy"]

Paper: Data from: The role of ecotype-environment interactions in intraspecific trophic niche partitioning subsequent to stocking
description: Worldwide, stocking of fish represent a valuable tool for conservation and maintenance of species exploited by recreational fishing. Releases of hatchery-reared fish are more and more recognized to have numerous demographic, ecological and genetic impacts on wild populations. However, consequences on intraspecific trophic relationships have rarely been investigated. In this study, we assessed the impacts of supplementation stocking and resulting introgressive hybridization on the trophic niches occupied by stocked, local and hybrid Lake Trout (Salvelinus namaycush) within populations of piscivorous and planktivorous ecotypes stocked from a wild piscivorous source population. We compared trophic niches using stable isotope analysis (13C and 15N) and trophic position among the three genetic origins. Putative genetic effects were tested with phenotype-genotype association of "life history" ecological traits (body size, growth rate, condition index and trophic niche) and genotypes (RADseq SNP markers) using redundant discriminant analysis (RDA). Results showed that sympatry resulting from the stocking of contrasting ecotypes is a risk factor for niche partitioning. Planktivorous populations are more susceptible to niche partitioning, by competitive exclusion of the local fish from a littoral niche to an alternative pelagic/profundal niche. Observed niche partitioning is probably a manifestation of competitive interactions between ecotypes. Our results emphasize that ecotypic variation should be considered for more efficient management and conservation practices and in order to mitigate negative impact of supplementation stocking.

['####### Cleaning workspace #########
rm(list=ls())

####### Loading required librairies #########
library(FSA)
library(nlstools)
library(dplyr)
library(SIBER)
library(lme4)
library(nlme)

####### Establish a work directory #########
setwd("/your_work_directory/")

############################ Comparison of isotopic values between muscle types (neck and dorsal) in same individuals ###################
####### Loading the data #########
data <- read.csv("/your_work_directory/SIA_muscle_comparison.csv", header=TRUE, sep=";", dec=".")

####### ANOVA among muscle type #########
fit_aov_C <- lm(d13C ~ muscle, data = data)
anova(fit_aov_C)

fit_aov_N <- lm(d15N ~ muscle, data = data)
anova(fit_aov_N)

############################ Calculation of Standard Ellipse Area (SEA) using the SIBER R package (Jackson et al. 2011) ###################
#This R script is largely inspired of SIBER vignette bye Andrew Jackson, available online.

####### Loading the data #########
rm(list=ls())
data <- read.csv("/your_work_directory/SIBER_all_populations.csv", header=TRUE, sep=";", dec=".")

####### Creating a siber object #########
siber.data <- createSiberObject(data)


####### Calculating the group metrics, including SEA and Total area (TA) #########
group.ML <- groupMetricsML(siber.data)
print(group.ML)

############################ Modelling of the Linear mixed effect model (LMEM) on SEA values ###################

####### Loading the data #########
rm(list=ls())
data <- read.csv("/your_work_directory/SEA_by_pop.csv", header=TRUE, sep=";", dec=".")

####### Valudation of data distribution #########
hist(sqrt(data$SEA), breaks=7)

####### Computation of the LMEM on SEA data #########
fit <- lme(fixed=sqrt(SEA) ~ ecotype + origin %in% ecotype, random = ~1|lake, data = data, na.action = na.omit)
summary(fit)
anova(fit)
lsmeans(fit, pairwise~origin, adjust="tukey")

####### Summary figure, figure 2 in Morissette et al. (2019) #########
data$origin <- ordered(data$origin, levels=c("Wild", "Local", "Hybrid", "Stocked"))
tiff("/your_work_directory/Figure_2.tiff", width = 3, height = 3, units = "in", res = 300)
par(mar = c(2,2.5,1,1))
boxplot(sqrt(SEA)~origin, data=data,
        cex=0.6, col = "light gray", boxwex = 0.6, ylim = c(0,3), cex.axis=0.6, cex.lab=0.7)
mtext("Log(Standard ellipse area)", side = 2, line=1.7, cex=0.7)
text(1,2.3,"A,B", cex=0.6)
text(2,1.8,"A", cex=0.6)
text(3,1.7,"A", cex=0.6)
text(4,2.5,"B", cex=0.6)

dev.off()



############################ Modelling of the Linear mixed effect model (LMEM) on stable isotope values ###################

####### Loading the data #########
rm(list=ls())
data <- read.csv("/your_work_directory/SIA_lake_trout.csv", header=TRUE, sep=";", dec=".")

####### LMEM of trophic position data ########
tp_model <- lme(fixed= trophic_position ~ ecotype + origin %in% ecotype + tl_cap %in% ecotype, random = ~1|lake, data = stk, na.action = na.omit)
summary(tp_model)
anova(tp_model)
lsmeans(tp_model, pairwise~origin, adjust="tukey")

####### LMEM of pelagic distance data ########
pel_model <- lme(fixed= delta_pelagic ~ ecotype + origin %in% ecotype + tl_cap %in% ecotype, random = ~1|lake, data = data, na.action = na.omit)
summary(pel_model)
anova(pel_model)
lsmeans(pel_model, pairwise~origin, adjust="tukey")



############################ Summary figure, figure 3 in Morissette et al. (2019) ############################

####### Data filtering #######
pisc <- filter(data, ecotype == "I") %>% droplevels()
pisc_L <- filter(pisc, origin =="L") %>% droplevels()
pisc_H <- filter(pisc, origin =="H") %>% droplevels()
pisc_E <- filter(pisc, origin =="E") %>% droplevels()
unstk_pisc <- filter(data, stocked == "N" & ecotype == "I" & lake != "Opeongo")%>% droplevels()


####### Data filtering #######
plank <- filter(data, ecotype == "P") %>% droplevels()
plank_L <- filter(plank, origin =="L") %>% droplevels()
plank_H <- filter(plank, origin =="H") %>% droplevels()
plank_E <- filter(plank, origin =="E") %>% droplevels()
unstk_plank <- filter(data, stocked == "N" & ecotype == "P")%>% droplevels()


####### Figure creation #######
tiff("/your_work_directory/Figure_3.tiff", height = 6, width =6, units = "in", res = 300)
par(mfrow = c(2,2), 
    mar = c(2,1,0,0), 
    oma = c(1,2,1,1))

boxplot(unstk_pisc$trophic_position,pisc_L$trophic_position, pisc_H$trophic_position, pisc_E$trophic_position, col = "light gray", 
        names = c("Wild", "Local","Hybrid", "Stocked"), outline=F, 
        ylim = c(4.5,6.4 ), cex = 0.7, boxwex = 0.7, axes = F)
axis(1, c(1,2,3,4), labels = c("Wild", "Local","Hybrid", "Stocked"), cex.axis = 0.8, mgp = c(0,0.5,0))
axis(2, seq(4.5, 6, 0.5), cex.axis = 0.8)
text(3.8,6.4, "Piscivorous", cex = 0.8)
text(1,6.4, "A")

boxplot(unstk_pisc$delta_pelagic,pisc_L$delta_pelagic, pisc_H$delta_pelagic, pisc_E$delta_pelagic, col = "light gray", 
        names = c("Wild", "L']

['# Load library
library(vegan)

Paper: Supplemental R code and csv files for statistical analysis on Doi et al. "Effects of species traits and ecosystem  characteristics on species detection by eDNA metabarcoding  in lake fish communities"
description: Supplemental R code and csv files for statistical analysis on Doi et al. "Effects of species traits and ecosystem characteristics on species detection by eDNA metabarcoding in lake fish communities"
content:
['
### 2022.2.14 
### Doi et al. Effects of species traits and ecosystem 
# characteristics on species detection by eDNA metabarcoding 
# in lake fish communities 

#library loading -------
library(tidyverse) 
library(lmerTest)
library(lme4)
library(lmer)
library(nlme)
library(lsmeans)
library(hier.part)
library(vegan)
library(iNEXT)
library(VennDiagram)
library(stringr)
library(gridExtra)
library(car)
library(ggpubr)
library(patchwork)
library(rfishbase)

#Deta (CSV) import -------
eDNAdata<-read.csv("eDNAlakes_data-re.csv")
eDNAsite<-read.csv("eDNAlakes_site.csv")
Fishdata<-read.csv("fish_historical_ori.csv")

eDNAsitelakemo<-read.csv("eDNAlakes_site_mor.csv")
eDNAsite2<-merge(eDNAsite,eDNAsitelakemo,by="lake")


#Dataframe subset -------
eDNAcomMor<-merge(eDNAsite2,eDNAdata, by="code")
eDNAcomMor<-subset(eDNAcomMor,eDNAcomMor$SampleType!="NC")
eDNAcomMor<-subset(eDNAcomMor,eDNAcomMor$SampleType!="Blank")
eDNAcom<-eDNAcomMor

eDNAcom2<-subset(eDNAcom,eDNAcom$SampleType=="Individual")
eDNAcom1L<-subset(eDNAcom,eDNAcom$SampleType=="Individual")
eDNAcom3<-subset(eDNAcom,eDNAcom$SampleType=="Mix_cold")
eDNAcomMc<-subset(eDNAcom,eDNAcom$SampleType=="Mix_cold")
eDNAcom4<-subset(eDNAcom,eDNAcom$SampleType=="Mix_freeze")
eDNAcomMf<-subset(eDNAcom,eDNAcom$SampleType=="Mix_freeze")


#Fig. 2 ---------
ggplot(data=eDNAcom5,aes(col=SampleType, x=SampleType, y=Total))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  geom_violin(alpha=0.2)+
  geom_jitter(width=0.2)+
  ylab("Number of fish taxa")+
  xlab("Sampling method")+
  theme_bw()+
  theme(legend.position = 'none')

eDNAcom2<-eDNAcom %>% group_by(SampleType) %>% 
  summarize(.[20:ncol(eDNAcom)], sum = mean())

eDNAcomlong<-pivot_longer(eDNAcom, 20:137, names_to = "spp", values_to = "reads")

eDNAcomL2<-eDNAcomlong %>% group_by(lake,SampleType,spp) %>% 
  summarise(sum = sum(reads)) 
  
eDNAcomL3<- eDNAcom2 %>% group_by(lake) %>% 
    summarise(Total=sum((sum>1)))

eDNAcomL3$SampleType<-"Individual total"
eDNAcomL4<-merge(eDNAcomL3,eDNAcom,by="lake")
eDNAcom_ext<-data.frame(eDNAcom[,c(2,5,19)])
eDNAcomL5<-rbind(eDNAcomL3,eDNAcom_ext)



#Nested ANOVA with LMM for Total spp.---------


model = lme(Total ~ SampleType, random=~1|lake, 
            data=eDNAcom5, 
            method="REML")

anova.lme(model, 
          type="sequential", 
          adjustSigma = FALSE)

leastsquare<-lsmeans(model, 
                      pairwise ~ SampleType, 
                      adjust="tukey")  
leastsquare



#list comparison --------

FishdataM<-Fishdata[,c(-2,-3,-4,-5)]
eDNAcom2M<-eDNAcom2[,c(-2,-3,-6,-7)]
FishdataM<-gather(FishdataM,key = species, value=detect, -lake)
eDNAcom2M<-gather(eDNAcom2M,key = species, value=detect, -lake,-SampleType,-code)

FishdataM<-subset(FishdataM,FishdataM$detect>3)
eDNAcom2M<-subset(eDNAcom2M,eDNAcom2M$detect>2)

FisheDNA<-merge(FishdataM,eDNAcom2M, by="lake")
write.csv(FisheDNA,file="FisheDNAMC.csv")
FisheDNA1L<-read.csv("FisheDNA_4.csv")
FisheDNAMc<-read.csv("FisheDNAMc.csv")
FisheDNAMf<-read.csv("FisheDNAMf.csv")

counttotal4<-FisheDNA4 %>%group_by(lake) %>% dplyr::summarise(count=sum(match)) 
counttotalMc<-FisheDNAMc %>%group_by(lake) %>% dplyr::summarise(count=sum(match)) 
counttotalMf<-FisheDNAMf %>%group_by(lake) %>% dplyr::summarise(count=sum(match)) 

counttotal4<-read.csv("counttotal-lake.csv")


#Fig.2 ------------

aa1<-ggplot(counttotal4, aes(col=method, y=count/Total*100, x=method))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  geom_violin(alpha=0.2)+
  geom_jitter(width=0.3)+
  ylab("Percentage of record covered")+
  xlab("Sampling method")+
  theme_bw()+
  theme(legend.position = 'none')
aa2<-ggplot(data=eDNAcom5,aes(col=SampleType, x=SampleType, y=Total))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  geom_violin(alpha=0.2)+
  geom_jitter(width=0.2)+
  ylab("Number of fish taxa")+
  xlab("Sampling method")+
  theme_bw()+
  theme(legend.position = 'none')

aa2+aa1+
  plot_annotation(
    tag_levels = "a",
    tag_suffix = ")"
  )


anov<-aov(count/Total~method:lake,counttotal4)
summary(anov)


library(nlme)
library(lsmeans)

counttotal4$count12<-counttotal4$count/counttotal4$Total12
counttotal4$count4<-counttotal4$count/counttotal4$Total
counttotal6<-counttotal4 %>% 
  tidyr::pivot_longer(c(-1,-2,-3,-4,-5,-6,-7), names_to = "counttype", values_to = "per")


model = lme(count/Total12 ~ method, random=~1|lake, 
            data=counttotal4, 
            method="REML")
model = lme(per ~ counttype+method, random=~1|lake, 
            data=counttotal6, 
            method="REML")


anova.lme(model, 
          type="sequential", 
          adjustSigma = FALSE)

leastsquare<-lsmeans(model, 
                     pairwise ~ method, 
                     adjust="tukey")  
leastsquare


#Fig.4----------

counttotal5<-merge(counttotal4,eDNAsitelakemo,by="lake")
counttotal5$MeanDepth<-as.numeric(counttotal5$MeanDepth)
counttotal5$Vol<-as.numeric(counttotal5$Vol)


g1<-ggplot(counttotal5, aes(col=method, y=count/Total*100, x=Lat))+
  geom_point()+
  xlab("Latitude")+
  stat_smooth(method="lm",fill = "grey90")+
  theme_bw(']

Paper: Data and analysis for "Fldgen v1.0: An Emulator with Internal Variability and Space-Time Correlation for Earth System Models"
description: This is an archive of the raw data and analysis source code for the paper "Fldgen v1.0: An Emulator with Internal Variability and Space-Time Correlation for Earth System Models". The archive contains:devel.Rmd : Source code for the worksheet that contains the early development and figures for the paper.devel.html : HTML rendering of devel.Rmdlg-ensemble-stats.Rmd : Source code for the worksheet that contains the statistical analysis described in the paper.lg-ensemble-stats.html : HTML rendering of lg-ensemble-stats.Rmdcc-analysis.Rmd : Analysis of the compromise conjecture raised by some readers of the papercc-analysis.nb.html : HTML rendering of cc-analysis.Rmddata.tar.bz2 : Input data for the analyses above.The source code in this archive is written in R and requires the R runtime environment. It also uses the fldgen package, version 1.0.0, which is available at https://github.com/JGCRI/fldgen

['## Function for calculating the power of a two-tailed F test for a hypothesized effect
## size.

## params:
## n1 - Number of degrees of freedom for the test set
## n2 - Number of degrees of freedom for the reference set
## delta - Effect size.  The fractional difference between the population
##         variances of the reference set and the test set.  So, if var(x2) =
##         1.3 var(x1), delta would be 0.3
## alpha - Intended p-value for the test
power.f <- function(n1, n2, delta, alpha)
{
    falpha <- qf(c(alpha/2.0, 1-alpha/2.0), n1, n2)

    pr <- sapply(c(1+delta, 1-delta),
                 function(k) {
                    fk <- falpha / k
                    pf(fk[1], n1, n2) + pf(fk[2], n1, n2, lower.tail=FALSE)
                 })
    min(pr)
}
', '## Determine the parameters for the beta function to use as a comparison
## hypothesis in determining the power of the Shapiro-Wilk test for normality.
## For each candidate value of n, compute the fraction of positive results in a
## suite of F-tests, at a specified p-value.  The two comparison distributions
## have the same variance (by construction), so there should be roughly that
## fraction of failures in the tests.  Substantially lower or higher failure
## rates indicate that the departure from normality is big enough to skew an
## F-test, and that is therefore a proxy for the threshold for a "de minimis"
## departure.
swcmpfn <- function(nsampobs, nsampmod, pval) {
    ## nsampobs: number of observational samples in each trial.  This should be similar to the
    ##        actual sample sizes.
    ## nsampmod: number of model samples in each trial
    ## pval: intended p-value to use for the f-test

    ntrial <- 2500          # number of trials for each candidate n value
    nvals <- seq(1:20)      # n values to try
    trialvec <- seq(1,ntrial)

    ## Sample a beta function with a specified n (= n1 = n2)
    sampbeta <- function(n) {
        rbeta(nsampmod, n, n)
    }

    ## Sample a normal distribution centered at 0.5 with the same variance as a beta distribution
    ## with the specified n
    sampnorm <- function(n) {
        s <- sqrt(1/(4*(1+2*n)))
        rnorm(nsampobs, mean=0.5, sd=s)
    }

    falpha <- c(pval/2, 1-pval/2)
    fc <- qf(falpha, nsampmod, nsampobs) # assumes F := var(model)/var(obs)

    ## Function to run the trials for each n
    runtrials <- function(n) {
        ## Function to run a single trial.  This will close over n
        run1trial <- function(index) {
            ## index is not used
            vbeta <- sampbeta(n)
            vnorm <- sampnorm(n)

            f <- var(vbeta)/var(vnorm)

            f < fc[1] | f > fc[2]       # return a single true-false value
        }

        ## return the fraction of positive (i.e., true) values
        sum(sapply(trialvec, run1trial)) / length(trialvec)
    }

    ## Run that function over all candidate n-values
    ffail <- sapply(nvals, runtrials)

    data.frame(n=nvals, frac.fail=ffail)
}


## Based on the tests above, even the 5,5 Beta distribution doesn't distort the
## F-test unduly, so we will use that as our alternative distribution.
pwr.sw <- function(nsampmod, pval, ntrial=1000)
{
    run1trial <- function(index) {
        ## index is not used

        ## generate a beta distribution data set.
        d <- rbeta(nsampmod, 5, 5)
        ## return true/false based on the p-value
        swpval(d) < pval
    }

    sum(sapply(seq(1:ntrial), run1trial)) / ntrial
}


## Helper function to run a Shapiro-Wilk test and get the p-value from the
## result structure, discarding the other stuff.
swpval <- function(x)
{
    tst <- shapiro.test(x)
    tst$p.value
}
']
keywords: data, analysis, Fldgen v1.0, emulator, internal variability, space-time correlation, earth system models, archive, raw data, source code, paper, worksheet, development, figures, statistical analysis, compromise conjecture, input data

Paper: Data from: Statistical analysis of dental variation in the Oligocene equid Miohippus (Mammalia, Perissodactyla) of Oregon
description: As many as eight species of the "anchitherine" equid Miohippus have been identified from the John Day Formation of Oregon, but no statistical analysis of variation in these horses has yet been conducted to determine if that level of diversity is warranted. Variation of the anterior-posterior length and transverse width of upper and lower teeth of Turtle Cove Member Miohippus was compared to that of M. equinanus, Mesohippus bairdii, Equus quagga, and Tapirus terrestris using t tests of their coefficients of variation (V). None of the t tests are significant, indicating that the variation seen in Turtle Cove Miohippus is not significantly different from any of the populations of other perissodactyls examined in this study. Data also indicate that Mesohippus is present in the Turtle Cove Member. Additionally, hypostyle condition, used to diagnose all species of Miohippus, was found to be related to stage of wear using an ordered logistic regression. Only two species of equid, one Miohippus and one Mesohippus, in the Turtle Cove Member can be identified, therefore only Miohippus annectens, the genotype and first species described from the region, can be recognized as the sole Miohippus species known from the Turtle Cove assemblage. There are insufficient data to determine which species of Mesohippus is present. The dependence of hypostyle condition on crown height in Miohippus implies that wear stage must also be considered in investigations of dental morphology in the "Anchitheriinae."
content:
['#This is code written by Nick Famoso to calculate an ordinal logit regression on data collected for Miohippus wear stages and Hypostyle condition
#Date:December 2014

#clear the memory
rm(list=ls())

#load the library
library(ordinal)
library(MASS)

data<-read.csv("Miohippus_Hypostyle.csv")

Hypostyle<-data$Hypostyle_condition
Hypostyle1<-data$Hypostyle_conditionA
Wear<-data$HI

#perform ordinal logistic regression
z<-polr(Hypostyle1~Wear, data = data, Hess=TRUE, method="logistic")
summary(z)

#present results with no p-value
(ctable <- coef(summary(z)))
#Get p-values
p<-pnorm(abs(ctable[,"t value"]), lower.tail=FALSE)*2
(ctable<-cbind(ctable, "pvalue" = p))


#run is without the M3
noM3<-data[ which(data$tooth!='M3'), ]

M3Hypostyle<-noM3$Hypostyle_condition
M3Hypostyle1<-noM3$Hypostyle_conditionA
M3Wear<-noM3$HI

#perform ordinal logistic regression
M3z<-polr(M3Hypostyle1~M3Wear, data = data, Hess=TRUE, method="logistic")
summary(M3z)

#present results with no p-value
(M3ctable <- coef(summary(M3z)))
#Get p-values
M3p<-pnorm(abs(M3ctable[,"t value"]), lower.tail=FALSE)*2
(M3ctable<-cbind(M3ctable, "pvalue" = M3p))']
keywords: dental variation, Oligocene equid, Miohippus, statistical analysis, Oregon, species diversity, upper teeth, lower teeth, perissodactyls, coefficients of variation, hypostyle condition, wear stage, Turtle Cove

Paper: Reduced seed set under water deficit is driven mainly by reduced flower numbers and not by changes in flower visitations and pollination
description: Water deficit can alter floral traits with cascading effects on flower-visitor interactions and plant fitness. Water stress induction can diminish productivity, directly resulting in lower flower production and consequently seed set. Changes in floral traits, such as floral scent or reward amount, may in turn alter pollinator visitations and behavior and consequently can reduce pollination services resulting in lower reproduction output. However, the relative contribution of this indirect in comparison to the direct effects of changes in seed set are not fully understood.We manipulated water availability using rain-out shelters in a field experiment and measured effects on floral scent bouquet, morphology, phenology, flower-visitor interactions, pollination, and seed set. Plant individuals of Sinapis arvensis (Brassicaceae) were randomly assigned to one of three treatments: mean precipitation (= control), reduced mean precipitation, or drought period treatment.Our results show that decreasing water availability lowers the number of flowers and seed set. This indicates a direct link between water stress and seed set, as seed mass increases with increasing flower number. The indirect link of water stress via floral traits, pollinator visits, and pollination has weaker effects on seed set. However, floral traits remain relatively stable under decreased water availability, whereas plant growth and flower abundance decrease, potentially in order to allow investment in more resources in fewer flowers to maintain pollination success. Thus, plants are able to compensate for water stress and can maintain floral trait expression, such as a stable scent emission and bouquet, to retain pollinator attraction.These findings indicate that the direct link from water stress to seed set has a stronger impact on plants' reproductive success than the indirect link through altered floral trait expression and pollinator visits in a generalist plant species.
content:
['######Libraries######
#Basic
library(data.table) #function setcolorder()
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr) ##data exploration and tidy up
library(plyr) ##Tools for Splitting, Applying and Combining Data
library(utils)

#Graphics
library(ggfortify)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggpubr) ## for scatter plots/ regressions
library(RColorBrewer)
library(semPlot) #plot piecewiseSEM 
library(rockchalk)
library(PupillometryR) # violine plots

#PCA
library(ade4) ## function dudi.pca()
library(factoextra) ## PCA

#Statistic
library(car)
library(corrplot)
library(DHARMa)
library(emmeans)
library(glmmTMB)
library(lme4) ##GLMMS, LMMS
library(mosaic) ## for function favstats()
library(piecewiseSEM) #Structural Equation Modelling
library(Matrix)
library(multcomp) ## Tukey-test
library(nlme)
library(report)
library(vegan) ##NMDS


#Create theme for graphs-----------------------------------------------
theme_MS <- function(){
  theme_bw() +
    theme(axis.text = element_text(size = 16), 
          axis.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
          axis.line.x = element_line(color="black"), 
          axis.line.y = element_line(color="black"),
          panel.border = element_blank(),
          panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),                                          
          panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
          panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
          panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),  
          plot.margin = unit(c(1, 1, 1, 1), 
                             units = , "cm"),
          plot.title = element_text(size = 18, 
                                    vjust = 1, 
                                    hjust = 0),
          legend.text = element_text(size = 12),          
          legend.title = element_blank(),                              
          legend.position = "NONE")
}

#********************************************************************************
#*********************************************************************************

# Set working directory and load data --------------------------------------------------------- 

setwd("")


###Import all data files----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

plantlist <- read.csv("Plantlist.csv", sep = ";") %>% # file with plant individual information (motherID, treatment...)
             mutate(treatment = factor(treatment,
                            levels = c("Control", "PrecipRed", "Drought"))) 


loggers <- read.csv("Loggerdata.csv", header=TRUE) # climate data logger files


soil <- read.csv("Soil_humi_temp.csv", header=TRUE, sep = ";") %>% # Soil conditions data file
        inner_join(plantlist) %>%
        group_by(plantID) %>%
        mutate(meantemperature = mean(temperature, na.rm=TRUE)) %>%
        mutate(meanhumidity = mean(humidity, na.rm=TRUE)) %>%
        distinct(plantID,.keep_all = TRUE)


# Floral trait files
Floral_trait_data <- read.csv("Floral_traits.csv", header=TRUE, sep=";")

scent_wide<- read.csv("Scent_data.csv", header=TRUE, sep = ",")

Floral_trait_data_complete <- Floral_trait_data %>%
                              left_join(scent_wide %>% dplyr::select(plantID, totalscent), 
                                        by="plantID") %>%
                              mutate(treatment = factor(treatment,
                                                        levels = c("Control", "PrecipRed", "Drought")))

#Load floral visitor data
Interaction_data <- read.csv("Int_data.csv", header=TRUE, sep=";")

  #Create wide format data table
      Interaction_data_wide <- Interaction_data %>%
                               dplyr::select(plantID, visitorgroup, NrInt_day_flower, treatment, shelter, motherID)%>%
                               group_by(visitorgroup) %>%
                               spread(visitorgroup, NrInt_day_flower)

      Interaction_data_wide[, 5:18][is.na(Interaction_data_wide[, 5:18])] <- 0
      Interaction_data_wide$totalint <- rowSums(Interaction_data_wide[,5:18]) # totalint = sum of all visits per day per flower for each plant 


      
#Summary statistic of interactions-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------    
  Interaction_data_stat <- Interaction_data %>%
        group_by(plantID) %>%
        distinct(plantID,.keep_all = TRUE)
      
      ##Mean days plants were observed
      mean(Interaction_data_stat$sumday) # mean number of days plants were observed 12.45
      sd(Interaction_data_stat$sumday) # standard deviation of number of days plants were observed = 3.65
      
      ##Mean observation time 
      mean(Interaction_data_stat$observetime) # mean observation time in min = 191.89
      sd(Interaction_data_stat$observetime) # standard deviation of observation time in min = 44.98
      
      
#Statistic stem water potential treatments---']

Paper: Data from: Multi-allelic exact tests for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium that account for gender
description: Statistical tests for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium are important elementary tools in genetic data analysis. X-chromosomal variants have long been tested by applying autosomal test procedures to females only, and gender is usually not considered when testing autosomal variants for equilibrium. Recently, we proposed specific X-chromosomal exact test procedures for bi-allelic variants that include the hemizygous males, as well as autosomal tests that consider gender. In this paper we present the extension of the previous work for variants with multiple alleles. A full enumeration algorithm is used for the exact calculations of triallelic variants. For variants with many alternate alleles we use a permutation test. Some empirical examples with data from the 1000 genomes project are discussed.
content:
['#
# R-code reconstructing tables of the paper "Multi-allelic exact tests for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium that account for gender"
#
# Molecular Ecology Resources: http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/1755-0998.12748
#

#install.packages(HardyWeinberg)
library(HardyWeinberg)

#
# Reconstructing Table 5 in Graffelman & Weir (2017) 
#

data("JPTtriallelicsChrX")
JPTtriallelicsChrX

Males   <- as.matrix(JPTtriallelicsChrX[,c("A","B","C")],ncol=3)
Females <- as.matrix(JPTtriallelicsChrX[,c("AA","AB","AC","BB","BC","CC")],ncol=6)

# Exact test HWP & EAF

out1.exa <- HWTriExact(Females[1,],Males[1,])
out2.exa <- HWTriExact(Females[2,],Males[2,])
out3.exa <- HWTriExact(Females[3,],Males[3,])
out4.exa <- HWTriExact(Females[4,],Males[4,])
out5.exa <- HWTriExact(Females[5,],Males[5,])
hwpandeafpval <- c(out1.exa$pval,
                   out2.exa$pval,
                   out3.exa$pval,
                   out4.exa$pval,
                   out5.exa$pval)

# Permutation tests for HWP & EAF

set.seed(123)
out1.perm <- HWPerm.mult(Males[1,],Females[1,])
out2.perm <- HWPerm.mult(Males[2,],Females[2,])
out3.perm <- HWPerm.mult(Males[3,],Females[3,])
out4.perm <- HWPerm.mult(Males[4,],Females[4,])
#out5.perm <- HWPerm.mult(Males[5,],Females[5,]) # time consuming
permpval <- c(out1.perm$pval,
              out2.perm$pval,
              out3.perm$pval,
              out4.perm$pval,
              NA)

# Exact test using females only

out1.exa.fem <- HWTriExact(Females[1,])
out2.exa.fem <- HWTriExact(Females[2,])
out3.exa.fem <- HWTriExact(Females[3,])
out4.exa.fem <- HWTriExact(Females[4,])
out5.exa.fem <- HWTriExact(Females[5,])
eaffempval <- c(out1.exa.fem$pval,
             out2.exa.fem$pval,
             out3.exa.fem$pval,
             out4.exa.fem$pval,
             out5.exa.fem$pval)

# Exact test for EAF only

out1.eaf <- EAFExact(Males[1,],toTriangular(Females[1,]))
out2.eaf <- EAFExact(Males[2,],toTriangular(Females[2,]))
out3.eaf <- EAFExact(Males[3,],toTriangular(Females[3,]))
out4.eaf <- EAFExact(Males[4,],toTriangular(Females[4,]))
out5.eaf <- EAFExact(Males[5,],toTriangular(Females[5,]))
eafpval <- c(out1.eaf$pval,
             out2.eaf$pval,
             out3.eaf$pval,
             out4.eaf$pval,
             out5.eaf$pval)
Table5 <- round(cbind(hwpandeafpval,permpval,eaffempval,eafpval),digits=4)
Table5

#
# Reconstructing Table 7 in Graffelman & Weir (2017) 
#

data("JPTmultiallelicsChrX")
attach(JPTmultiallelicsChrX)

out.hwp_eaf.4 <- HWPerm.mult(m4,f4)
out.hwp_fem.4 <- HWPerm.mult(f4)
out.eaf.4 <- EAFExact(m4,f4)
results.4 <- c(out.hwp_eaf.4$pval,out.hwp_fem.4$pval,out.eaf.4$pval)

out.hwp_eaf.5 <- HWPerm.mult(m5,f5)
out.hwp_fem.5 <- HWPerm.mult(f5)
out.eaf.5 <- EAFExact(m5,f5)
results.5 <- c(out.hwp_eaf.5$pval,out.hwp_fem.5$pval,out.eaf.5$pval)

out.hwp_eaf.6 <- HWPerm.mult(m6,f6)
out.hwp_fem.6 <- HWPerm.mult(f6)
out.eaf.6 <- EAFExact(m6,f6)
results.6 <- c(out.hwp_eaf.6$pval,out.hwp_fem.6$pval,out.eaf.6$pval)

out.hwp_eaf.7 <- HWPerm.mult(m7,f7)
out.hwp_fem.7 <- HWPerm.mult(f7)
out.eaf.7 <- EAFExact(m7,f7)
results.7 <- c(out.hwp_eaf.7$pval,out.hwp_fem.7$pval,out.eaf.7$pval)

Table7 <- round(rbind(results.4,results.5,results.6,results.7),digits=4)
Table7

detach(JPTmultiallelicsChrX)

#
# Reconstructing Table 8 in Graffelman & Weir (2017) 
#

data("JPTtriallelicsChr7")

Males <- JPTtriallelicsChr7[,3:8]
colnames(Males) <- substr(colnames(Males),2,3)

Females <- JPTtriallelicsChr7[,9:14]
colnames(Females) <- substr(colnames(Females),2,3)

# test HWP & EAF

out1.hwe_eaf <- HWTriExact(Males[1,],Females[1,])
out2.hwe_eaf <- HWTriExact(Males[2,],Females[2,])
out3.hwe_eaf <- HWTriExact(Males[3,],Females[3,])
out4.hwe_eaf <- HWTriExact(Males[4,],Females[4,])
out5.hwe_eaf <- HWTriExact(Males[5,],Females[5,])
out6.hwe_eaf <- HWTriExact(Males[6,],Females[6,])
Results.hwe_eaf <- c(out1.hwe_eaf$pval,out2.hwe_eaf$pval,out3.hwe_eaf$pval,
                     out4.hwe_eaf$pval,out5.hwe_eaf$pval,out6.hwe_eaf$pval)

# test HWP in the total sample

Total <- Males+Females

out1.t <- HWTriExact(Total[1,])
out2.t <- HWTriExact(Total[2,])
out3.t <- HWTriExact(Total[3,])
out4.t <- HWTriExact(Total[4,])
out5.t <- HWTriExact(Total[5,])
out6.t <- HWTriExact(Total[6,])
Results.hwp.t <- c(out1.t$pval,out2.t$pval,out3.t$pval,
                   out4.t$pval,out5.t$pval,out6.t$pval)

# test HWP in females only

out1.f <- HWTriExact(Females[1,])
out2.f <- HWTriExact(Females[2,])
out3.f <- HWTriExact(Females[3,])
out4.f <- HWTriExact(Females[4,])
out5.f <- HWTriExact(Females[5,])
out6.f <- HWTriExact(Females[6,])
Results.hwp.f <- c(out1.f$pval,out2.f$pval,out3.f$pval,
                   out4.f$pval,out5.f$pval,out6.f$pval)


# test HWP in males only

out1.m <- HWTriExact(Males[1,])
out2.m <- HWTriExact(Males[2,])
out3.m <- HWTriExact(Males[3,])
out4.m <- HWTriExact(Males[4,])
out5.m <- HWTriExact(M']

Paper: Future number of people with diagnosed type 1 diabetes in Germany until 2040
description: Data and source file for estimation of the incidence of type 1 diabetes (T1D) and projection of the prevalence and number of people living with T1D in future Germany. Prevalence input is based on a huge German claims data set based on aggregated data. The additional data files (text files) provide population projections published by the German Federal Statistical Office (see https://www.destatis.de/EN/Themes/Society-Environment/Population/Population-Projection/_node.html;jsessionid=6642087EED703DD77DFB9CB076205246.live712).All files are text files. The file with the extension .R is the source file for use with the open statistical software R (The R Foundation of Scientific Computing).
keywords: Type 1 diabetes, Germany, incidence, prevalence, projection, population, statistics, data set, claims data, Federal Statistical Office, R software, estimation.

Paper: Data for: Open COVID Trials (OCT) Project
description: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought substantial attention to the systems used to communicate biomedical research. In particular, the need to rapidly and credibly communicate research findings has led many stakeholders to encourage researchers to adopt open science practices such as posting preprints and sharing data. To examine the degree to which this has led to the actual adoption of such practices, we examined the "openness" of a sample of 539 published papers describing the results of randomized controlled trials testing interventions to prevent or treat COVID-19. The majority (56%) of the papers in this sample were free to read at the time of our investigation and 23.56% were preceded by preprints. However, there is no guarantee that the papers without an open license will be available without a subscription in the future, and only 49.61% of the preprints we identified were linked to the subsequent peer-reviewed version. Of the 331 papers in our sample with statements identifying if (and how) related datasets were available, only a paucity indicated that data was available in a repository that facilitates rapid verification and reuse. Our results demonstrate that, while progress has been made, there is still a significant mismatch between aspiration and actual practice in the adoption of open science in an important area of the COVID-19 literature.
content:
['## Covid clinical trial meta-analysis
## cyp v-2022

library("ggplot2")
library("waffle")
library("dplyr")

# XXX set working directory
wd <- "~/Desktop/oct_dataset"
setwd(wd)
# load data
data <- read.csv("./oct-dataset_for-manuscript_2022-08-03.csv",header=T)

### Paper t-tests
## ICMJE member journals vs not for citations
# t = -5.3182, df = 104.35, p-value = 6.007e-07 (mean no: 41.98152, mean yes: 617.79048 ) - S
t.test(as.numeric(citations_dimensions)~icmje_member,data=data)
## ICMJE member journals vs not for altmetrics
# t = -6.3867, df = 106.79, p-value = 4.51e-09 (mean no: 306.1039, mean yes: 3419.8491 ) - S
t.test(as.numeric(altmetric_score)~icmje_member,data=data)
## ICMJE recommendations (i.e. follow?) vs not for citations
# t = -4.7315, df = 275.35, p-value = 3.567e-06 (mean no: 45.38148, mean yes: 264.15299) - S
t.test(as.numeric(citations_dimensions)~icmje_follow,data=data)
## ICMJE recommendations (i.e. follow?) vs not for altmetrics
# t = -5.37, df = 306.75, p-value = 1.558e-07 (mean no: 317.3444, mean yes: 1521.7993) - S
t.test(as.numeric(altmetric_score)~icmje_follow,data=data)
## Preprints found vs not for citations
# t = -0.55581, df = 198.6, p-value = 0.579 (mean no: 146.8297, mean yes: 178.7323) - NS
t.test(as.numeric(citations_dimensions)~preprint_found,data=data)
## Preprints found vs not for altmetrics
# t = -0.41217, df = 345.58, p-value = 0.6805 (mean no: 897.6156, mean yes: 985.3672) - NS
t.test(as.numeric(altmetric_score)~preprint_found,data=data)


## Paper figures
data_avail_request <- paste(data$data_avail_statement,data$data_avail_request_author,sep="_")
# A) to photoshop legend
# availability statement? no, yes --> available by request? no, yes
waffle(table(data_avail_request),colors=c("#D3D3D3","#708090","#DA614E"),xlab="1 square = 1 publication",rows=20,size=0.5)

# B)
data_avail_repo <- paste(data$data_avail_statement,data$data_avail_repo,sep="_")
# availability statement? no, yes --> available by repo? no, yes
waffle(table(data_avail_repo),colors=c("#D3D3D3","#708090","#4EC7DA"),xlab="1 square = 1 publication",rows=20,size=0.5)

']
keywords: open COVID trials, COVID-19 pandemic, biomedical research, open science, preprints, data sharing, randomized controlled trials, interventions, open license, subscription, peer-reviewed version, datasets, repository, verification, reuse, aspiration, actual practice.

content:
['# Read the raw counts
library(DESeq2);library(ggplot2);library(reshape2);library(RColorBrewer)
library(EnsDb.Hsapiens.v86);library(ggrepel);library(fgsea);library(tidyverse);library(corrplot);
library(Hmisc);

gtf = rtracklayer::import('Data/Homo_sapiens.GRCh38.103.gtf')
gtf_df = as.data.frame(gtf)
heat_colors = brewer.pal(6, "YlOrRd")

###############################
### WAGA ####
###############################
waga = read.table("Data/ont_pipeline/WAGA/counts/waga_all_gene_counts.tsv")
colnames(waga) = gsub("_.+","",colnames(waga))

# Specific to MKL1 since barcode 3 failed
designMatrix = read.table("Data/ont_pipeline/WAGA/DesignMatrixWAGA.txt")
colnames(designMatrix) = c("Samples","Condition")
designMatrix$Samples = colnames(waga)
dds = DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = waga,colData = designMatrix,design = ~Condition)
dds = DESeq(dds)
plotDispEsts(dds, main= "dispEst: waga")

# Lists the coefficients
res = results(dds, name=resultsNames(dds)[2])
res = as.data.frame(res)
res = res[complete.cases(res),]
resSig = res[res$padj < 0.1 & abs(res$log2FoldChange) > 1,]

# Formating of ENSG
geneIDs = ensembldb::select(EnsDb.Hsapiens.v86, keys = rownames(res), keytype = "GENEID", columns = c("SYMBOL","GENEID"))
rownames(geneIDs) = geneIDs$GENEID
res$symbol = geneIDs[rownames(res),1]
res["LargeT-Antigen","symbol"] = "Large-T-Antigen"
resSig$symbol = geneIDs[rownames(resSig),1]
rm(geneIDs)

res = res[,c("symbol","baseMean","log2FoldChange","pvalue","padj")]
resSig = resSig[,c("symbol","baseMean","log2FoldChange","padj")]

norm_counts = as.data.frame(counts(dds,normalized = T))
norm_counts_waga = norm_counts
res = cbind(res,norm_counts[rownames(res),])
res = res[complete.cases(res),]
outpath = paste0("Analysis/","waga-results-unfiltered.tsv")
write.table(res,file=outpath,sep="\t",row.names = F)

threshold = 0.01
library(ggrepel)

# VOLCANO PLOT
mycolors = c("green", "red", "black")
names(mycolors) = c("UP", "DOWN", "NO")

res$diff = "NO"
res$diff[res$log2FoldChange > 1 & res$padj < 0.1] <- "UP"
res$diff[res$log2FoldChange < -1 & res$padj < 0.1] <- "DOWN"
res$label[res$diff != "NO"] = res$symbol[res$diff != "NO"]

ggplot(res)+
  geom_point(aes(x = log2FoldChange, y = -log10(pvalue),col=diff)) +
  geom_text_repel(data=res,mapping = aes(x = log2FoldChange,-log10(pvalue),label = label)) +
  scale_colour_manual(values = mycolors)+
  ggtitle("WAGA") +
  theme_bw(base_size = 15)+
  xlab("log2 fold change") + 
  ylab("-log10 p-value") +
  #geom_vline(xintercept=c(-1, 1), col="red",linetype="longdash")+
  #geom_hline(yintercept=-log10(0.1), col="red",linetype="longdash")+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = scales::pretty_breaks(n = 15)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = scales::pretty_breaks(n = 10)) +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        plot.title = element_text(size = rel(1.5), hjust = 0.5),
        axis.title = element_text(size = rel(1.25))) 

####
rownames(designMatrix) = designMatrix$Sample

vsd = vst(dds, blind=FALSE)
pcaData = plotPCA(vsd, intgroup=c("Condition"), returnData=TRUE)
percentVar = round(100 * attr(pcaData, "percentVar"))
ggplot(pcaData, aes(PC1, PC2, color=Condition)) +
  geom_point(size=3) +
  xlab(paste0("PC1: ",percentVar[1],"% variance")) +
  ylab(paste0("PC2: ",percentVar[2],"% variance")) + 
  coord_fixed()

vsd = as.data.frame(assay(vsd))
vsd = vsd[row.names(resSig),]
rownames(designMatrix) = designMatrix$Sample
resSig = resSig[order(resSig$log2FoldChange,decreasing = T),]
vsd = vsd[rownames(resSig),]

pheatmap::pheatmap(vsd,
                   color = heat_colors,
                   cellwidth = 30,
                   cellheight = 30,
                   show_colnames = F,
                   cluster_rows = F,
                   cluster_cols =  T,
                   border_color = NA,
                   labels_row = resSig$symbol,
                   fontsize = 7,
                   annotation_col = designMatrix[,c(2),drop=F],
                   annotation_row = resSig[,c(4,3),drop = F],
                   main = "WAGA - VSD normaliszed",
                   angle_col = "45")


#############################
####### MKL1 ################
#############################

mkl1 = read.table("Data/ont_pipeline/MKL1/counts/mkl1_all_gene_counts.tsv")
colnames(mkl1) = gsub("_.+","",colnames(mkl1))
# Specific to MKL1 since barcode 3 failed
mkl1 = mkl1[,-3]
designMatrix = read.table("Data/ont_pipeline/MKL1/DesignMatrixMKL1.txt")
colnames(designMatrix) = c("Samples","Condition")
designMatrix$Samples = colnames(mkl1)
dds = DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = mkl1,colData = designMatrix,design = ~Condition)
dds = DESeq(dds)
plotDispEsts(dds, main= "dispEst: mkl1")

# Lists the coefficients
res = results(dds, name=resultsNames(dds)[2])
res = as.data.frame(res)
res = res[complete.cases(res),]
resSig = res[res$padj < 0.1 & abs(res$log2FoldChange)>1,]

# Formating of ENSG
geneIDs = ensembldb::select(EnsDb.Hsapiens.v86, keys = rownames(res), keytype = "GENEID", columns = c("SYMBOL","GENEID"))
rownames(geneIDs) = geneIDs$GEN']
